WILLIAM THOMAS ARTHUR (policeman, R 202). On Saturday night about nine o'clock Greenwood complained to me—I went with him to dif
ferent houses, but could not find the party—on Sunday evening about six he came and took me to the prisoner's house—she was standing at the door—I asked her if a female had been in there ten minutes or quarter of an hour ago, she said, "No"—I said, "Have you lodgers?" she said, "No"—she was very much confused—Greenwood said, "That is the woman you want"—I said, "Are you sure of that?"—he said, "Quite positive"—I asked the prisoner if she knew him—she said, "I believe he lives at the beer-shop over the way "—he said, "Yes, you know I do, you are the party that robbed me "—I asked her to produce the bonnet and shawl she had on yes
terday—she put on a light shawl and black bonnet.

Cross-examined. Q. You had no notion she was the person? A. Deci
dedly not—I have known her for years—she is a very respectable woman—
she said he was a very wicked boy for saying she was the woman—her house is forty or fifty yards from the spot—the beer-shop is two hundred yards further on—it is a public place.
NOT GUILTY .

2017.
BRIDGET LLOYD
, stealing 1 sheet, 1 petticoat, and 2 yards of drugget, value 1s. 6d.; the goods of
Robert Baldery.
ROBERT BALDERY . I am a baker, at Woolwich. On 11th July, about twelve o'clock at night, I lost some sheeting and petticoats—I received them from my daughter, next morning—these are them (produced).

HARRIET BALDERY . I am sixteen years old. I met the prisoner in, Wellington-street—she was not a friend of mine—she said she took some clothes, and if I would go with her to her house she would show them me—I went, and found the petticoat and drugget in her yard—they are my father's.
Prisoner's Defence. I found the things in the yard, and took them in; next morning I forgot to say anything about them.

ROBERT BALDERY
re-examined. It is a mixed yard, not ours only.
NOT GUILTY .

2018.
BRIDGET LLOYD was again indicted
for stealing 1 chair, value 2s.; the goods of
Robert Hitchcock.
ROBERT HITCHCOCK . On 11th July I lost a chair—I received information, and found it at the prisoner's house, all broken.
Prisoner's Defence. I bought in the street.

GUILTY . Aged 26.—
Confined Four Months.

2019.
CHARLOTTE GIBBS
, stealing 1 shift. 1 night-cap, 1 collar, 1 apron, and 1 napkin, value 1s. 9d.; the goods of
James Appleby.

MARY ANN APPLEBY . I am the wife of James Appleby. On 1st Aug. I had a bundle, containing a shift, a night-cap, an apron, and a napkin—I was with the prisoner in a public-house—I went out, returned, and missed her and the bundle.
Prisoner. It was my bundle; we each had one at the public-house. Witness. She had no bundle when she left me.
JOHN GRIFFIN (policeman, R 229). I took the prisoner in a kitchen, in Warren-lane, Woolwich, with a bundle—she said it was hers.

GUILTY . Aged 36.—
Confined Three Months.
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

2020.
JAMES BARNES
, stealing 3 pewter-pots, value 3s.; the goods of
John Munn.
JOHN MUNN . I keep the Hare and Billet, at Blackheath. These pots are mine (produced)—I lost them—the prisoner lived two or three hundred yards from me.

Cross-examined by MR. PARNELL. Q. Does he-deal with you? A. Yes—he is a blacksmith—he has fetched beer for his supper, and my potman has fetched the pots in the morning—I put two of these pots by my stable-door, and one across the road.

JOHN TAYLOR (policeman). On 31st July, between five and six o'clock in the morning, I secreted myself, and saw the prisoner come from his forge, and look about him—he picked up a pot from the road, near the tip-room window, put it under his apron, and returned towards his house—three pots were standing in the road—he took two, put them under his apron, went to his forge, and locked the door—my brother constable knocked—he did not open
it—the half-door was not fastened—we went in, and found one pint and two quart pots on a bench.
Cross-examinrd. Q. Is not he quite deaf? A. Yes—he has lived there respectably more than nine years—you could reach the pots from the door.
NOT GUILTY .

2021.
JAMES BARNES was again indicted
for stealing 1 pewter pot value 1s.; the goods of
Charles Evans.
CHARLES EVANS . I lost a pot—this is it (produced).
GEORGE WADE . On Sunday evening I put a pot by Mr. Dowsett's wharf—I did not see it again till it was at the station.
JOHN TAYLOR (policeman). I saw the prisoner come from his house at five o'clock, and take this pot, wrapped it in his apron, and took it into his forge.
NOT GUILTY .

2022.
ELIZABETH STYLES
, stealing 1 waistcoat, 2 pillow-cases, and other articles, value 20l.; the goods of
John Frederick Copland, her master.

MARY ANN COPLAND . I am the wife of Frederick John Copland, of Willow-terrace, Charlton. I lost these things, and charged the prisoner with stealing them—she was my servant—I went with a policeman, searched her lodgings, and found twenty-six duplicates, by which I found these articles at the pawnbroker's—they were all in my charge.
EDWARD SCOTT (policeman, K 47). I went with Mr. Copland, and found these twenty-six duplicates (produced) on the table, in the prisoner's room.
THOMAS MARSON . I produce a sheet, table-cloth, and two pillow-cases, pawned in the name of Elizabeth Smith—I gave the person this duplicate.
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Confined Nine Months.

2023.
CATHERINE HERRION
, stealing 1 half-crown, 11d., 2 half-pence, and 1 farthing; the goods of
James Figg; having been before con
victed.

HARRIET FIGG . I am the daughter of James Figg. On 30th June, about nine o'clock, the prisoner and another young woman came and called for two glasses of porter—my father brought it—I saw the prisoner put her hand into the till, take some halfpence, and put them into her pocket—I missed half-a-crown from the till—I saw her take some more halfpence off the counter—I told my father.
Cross-examined by MR. CLERK. Q. Was she drunk? A. I think she was the worse for liquor—she seemed to know what she was about.
SARAH EVELEIGH . I searched the prisoner at the station, and found a half-crown, eleven pence, two halfpence, and a farthing—she was very tipsy.
HENRY BURNS (policeman, R 261). I produce a certificate of the prisoner's conviction—(read—Convicted Sept., 1847, and confined two months)—she is the person.

GUILTY .—
Confined One Year.

2024.
WILLIAM JOHNSON and
THOMAS WILLIAMS
, stealing 1 purse, value 1s.; 4 shillings, 2 sixpences, and 3 groats, the property of
John Rees; from the person of
Eliza D'Oyley Rees.

ELIZA D'OYLEY REES . I am the wife of John Rees. On 14th July, I was at Sir Thomas Wilson's fete, at Charlton—an officer spoke to me—I missed my purse from my right-hand pocket—there were shillings, sixpences, and fourpenny pieces in it—this is it.
Cross-examined by MR. METCALFE. Q. How do you know it? A. I have had it two years—I looked at it before I left my house.
Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. Had you seen the prisoners? A. Yes, in front of the garden—not three minutes before White spoke to me.

JOHN WHITE (policeman, R 180). I was on duty at Sir Thomas Wilson's on the afternoon of 14th July, there was a fete there—I saw the prisoners together, watched them about a quarter of an hour, and saw them go both toge
ther, and stand beside Mrs. Rees—Williams lifted her pocket, or her dress—Johnson covered him—they then left—I went and spoke to her, and then took Johnson—I said, "Hand me over that purse"—he said he had no purse—he then took it from his pocket, and threw it on the ground—I called to my brother officer to take it up.

Cross-examined by MR. METCALFE. Q. Did you see it when he took it out? A. Yes, and tried to get it—there was not much of it visible—I saw it was something red—when it was on the ground I could see that it was a purse—Gladwin picked it up—I was tustling with the prisoner—I saw a form with ladies and gentlemen on it—Mrs. Rees stood with her back to it—there were persons in front of her—there were persons on the form looking over her head, and of course over Williams's head.
Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. Were you behind Williams? A. Yes—Johnson hid him—I took Johnson from twenty-five to thirty yards from the spot.

WILLIAM GLADWIN (policeman, R 122). I was with the other officer at Sir Thomas Wilson's—I saw the prisoners together—Williams went to Mrs. Rees, and apparently put his hand into her pocket—Johnson covered him—Williams took something from the pocket, and gave it to Johnson, who put it into his pocket, and they both walked away—I spoke to Mrs. Rees—I then saw Johnson in White's custody—I took Williams—White said, "Look out, he has dropped the purse on the ground"—I found this purse on the ground—it has shillings, sixpences, and fourpenny pieces in it.

JOHN CARPENTER (policeman, R 4). I was on duty, and watched the prisoners—Williams attempted to pick a lady's pocket—he then went behind Mrs. Rees—I stood behind the form, and separated two ladies' dresses with my hand, looked through, and saw Williams take from Mrs. Rees's pocket a red purse—he had a handkerchief in his hand wiping his mouth with it—he wrapped it in the handkerchief, and passed it to Johnson—I took this hand
kerchief from Williams—I heard Johnson say he had no purse.

Cross-examined by MR. METCALFE. Q. Did you state this before the Magistrate? A. Yes, on cross-examination—I was in plain clothes—I be
long to the Detective Force of the R division—there were five or six thou
sand persons there.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. Were you behind the others? A. I was behind the form which was between me and Mr. Rees; I have been a policeman nearly twelve years—I believe that I did right to state that I saw Williams try one pocket before—I believe it is my duty to state all I saw the prisoners do on that occasion—I should not have allowed them to commit more than one robbery if I could have helped it, but if I could not, I should have stated what I had seen—I am aware that to attempt is an offence, and a summary conviction would have been the consequence—the form was five or six feet long—I was about the middle of it, or if anything, rather nearer to the end where the prisoners were—it was perhaps a yard and a half from Mrs. Rees—I was looking to her left side.

JOHNSON—
GUILTY . Aged 34.—
Transported for Seven Years.

WILLIAMS—
GUILTY . Aged 14.—
Confined Twelve Months.

2025.
GEORGE HUGHES
, stealing 1 coat, value 3s., the goods of
William Charles Dewick.

WILLIAM CHARLES DEWICK . I am a coachman of Blackhead). I was in the service of the proprietor of the Green Man. On 16th Aug. last year, I put my coat in a carriage in the coach-house about half-past one or two o'clock in the clay—I missed it about seven at night—I found it next morn
ing at Mr. Sharp's, a pawnd-oker, at Deptford—I got it out,. and. I have it on now—it is mine—I know the prisoner by sight—I cannot swear that I had seen him that day.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Was there anything particular going on at Blackheath that day? A. Yes, a foot-race—there were many people about, and many people came in the yard no doubt—I fetched the tailor to swear to my coat before I took it out, but I had no doubt of its being mine—he said he made it for me—there was an old silk handkerchief in the pocket, and the coat was tied up in that handkerchief, which I knew, and had had a long time.

JOHN ACKLAND . I am a coachman. I was in the employ of the pro
prietor of the Green Man—I recollect the foot-race Last Aug.—the prisoner came there about five o'clock—I heard Dewick speak about this business that day.

Cross-examined. Q. What makes you recollect that the prisoner came that day? A. He was a fellow-servant of mine, and came to see me—I did not see him go away—I left him to go to see the race—I know he came down on the day of the race to fetch some little things he had left at the Green Man with me—I have seen him once since.

JAMES SHARP . I am an assistant to Joseph Sharp, a pawnbroker at Deptford. On 16th Aug. last year, a coachman's blue coat, of this descrip
tion, was pawned with me, I do not recollect by whom—the person had this ticket given him—I let Dewick have it.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you give it up next day? A. My employer did; I was present—I am quite sure it was the coat that was pawned the day before—I did not see the duplicate again till it was brought on 30th June this year—I had not the coat to produce then.

RICHARD MINOR . I am in the service of Mr. Riches, of Clapham-com
mon. I saw the prisoner at a public-house three or four months ago—he asked if I wanted a coat—I said I did not know that I did, what sort of coat was it—he said a blue frock coat, with velvet collar, and pockets at the sides—I said, "How much do you want for it?"—he said, "I don't want to sell it, it is in pawn at Deptford, but I will give you the duplicate, provided you will et it out"—I said, "How do you know it will fit me"—he said, "Because it fits me, and you are about the same stamp"—I said, "Then you knew the man it belonged to?"—he said, "Yes, he was a groom, who left service, and took a cab, and is now gone to Australia "—he gave me this duplicate—I kept it till 30th June—I sent it to the pawnbroker by my nephew.
JAMES MINOR . I took the duplicate to the pawnbroker.

JOHN CARPENTER (policeman, R 84). I took the prisoner—I asked him if he pawned a coat at Mr. Sharp's—he said he had not—I asked him if he had had the ticket of a coat pawned at Mr. Sharp's—he said, "No"—I said, "Did you not gave a ticket of a coat to a man named Minor, living at Clap
ham?"—he said, "Yes, I did "—he said he had the duplicate of a man he did not know at a public-house in the Kent-road for a pot of beer.
NOT GUILTY .

2025.
RICHARD ILES
, stealing 1 spoke-shave, value 2s.; the goods of
Robert Fitch; 1 hammer, 1 screw-driver, and 1 pair of compasses, value 4s. 6d.; the goods of
Samuel Browning.

ROBERT FITCH . I am a carpenter, and was working at Berners-street, Greenwich. The prisoner was working there, in the employ of the con
tractor—on 14th Aug. I lost this spoke-shave (produced)—I am sure it is mine.
SAMUEL BROWNING . I was working at the building—I lost a screw-driver and pair of compasses—these are them.
Prisoner. Q. Were not you, and I, and the builder's son, drinking all day from eleven o'clock till we left off? A. Part of the time we were—I was tipsy, and fell between the joists.

JOHN CARPENTER (policeman, 84 R). I received information, went to a pawnbrokers, and saw these tools handed to the prisoner—he paid money for them—he took part of them—I took the rest—I said, "These are the things I am in search of, and I am in search of you also for stealing them"—he said, "I am very sorry, I pawned them here on Monday; if you will allow me I will take them back."

Prisoner's Defence. I went to work; they called me down to pay my footing; I had but 1s. 6d.; I spent that, and a young man said, "Can't we raise some money by taking some tools?"—Browning authorised me to pawn them—I said I would get them again.

SAMUEL BROWNING
re-examined. I paid for part that I drank, but these things were pawned afterwards—I left a boy to take my tools in—the boy was moving the boards, and I slipped down—the prisoner denied having had the tools the next morning.
WILLIAM ELLIS . I called at the house about half-past two o'clock—the prisoner, and the plasterers and carpenters were all drinking together—Browning was so much intoxicated he could not stand.
NOT GUILTY .

2026.
ARTHUR LEARY and
RICHARD COOPER
, unlawfully utter
ing counterfeit coin.

ELIZA PERRIAN . My husband keeps the Joiner's Arms, beer-shop, at Lewisham. On 20th July, about twelve o'clock in the day, the prisoner Cooper came and asked for half a pint of porter—it came to a penny—he gave me a bad half-crown—I looked at it, threw it down, and told him it was bad—he snatched it up instantly, and gave me a good one—he went out and I sent a boy to follow him—I saw Cooper join Leary and another—they went to Lee.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. How far were the other persons from you? A. About 100 yards—I had never seen Cooper before—he was at our place about two minutes.

ELIZABETH BOOKER . My husband keeps the Highlander, at Lee, about a mile from the Joiner's Arms. On 26th July, Leary came there about half-past twelve o'clock, and asked for a pint of beer which came to twopence—he gave me a bad half-crown—I gave him the change—he left—I thought it was not good, and laid it on a shelf—there was no other money there—my brother was standing at the door—I called his attention to the half-crown, about ten minutes after Leary was gone—he took it and went after Leary.
Cross-examined. Q. Where do you generally put money? A. In the

till—I suspected at first it was bad—I am sure I got it from Leary—no customer came in from the time I placed it on the shelf, till I asked my brother about it—I did not throw it in a place where there was other money—there is a bowl kept in the till, which is a drawer in the bottom shelf of the cupboard—when I receive money I go to the cupboard—I laid the half-crown on the third shelf, distinct from the till.

WILLIAM BOOKER . On 26th July my sister gave me this half-crown—I saw it was bad—I went in pursuit of Leary—I saw him and Cooper, about ten rods off on the right, on the road to Lee—I followed and cave them in charge at the Tigier's Head—on going along the road they fell in conver
sation with another man—I gave the half-crown my sister gave me, to the sergeant.

JAMES JENKINS (police-sergeant, R 10). Booker came to me—I went to the Tiger's Head, and saw the prisoners in conversation—the other man had left hem—Leary was about to enter the Tiger's Head—I took him and Cooper to the station—I found this half-crown in Leary's hand—I was about to search Cooper—he took his right hand from his pocket, and in it was this half-crown—I bent the two half-crowns between my teeth, and found they were bad—I found a penny on each of the prisoners—this is the half-crown I received from Booker.
CALEB EDWARD POWELL . I am inspector of coin to the Royal Mint. These three half-crowns are all counterfeit, and have all been cast in the same mould.

LEARY—
GUILTY . Aged 37.

COOPER—
GUILTY . Aged 44.

2027.
HENRY WILSON
, stealing 2 shillings, 4 sixpences, and 4 groats, the moneys of
Frederick Andrew Hall; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Three Months.

2028.
ANN BROWNE
, stealing 2 sovereigns and two half-sovereigns, the monies of
Francis William Thorn.

MARTHA THORN . I am the wife of Francis William Thorn—the prisoner lodged with us in Plumstead-road. I had two sovereigns and two half-sovereigns in an egg-cup—the prisoner came on 22nd July—I was ironing—she asked me to let her iron a shirt, but I did not—my sister and her husband were up stairs—they did not come down—I went out for about ten minutes—when I came back the prisoner was gone and the money.
JOHN JONES (policeman). The prisoner came to the station, and said she could not rest easy; she had robbed her landlady of two sovereigns and two half-sovereigns.
Prisoners Defence. I took it and gave myself up; I had no home to go to; my husband said he would pay the money back again.

GUILTY . Aged 30.—
Confined Six Months.

2029.
ROBERT SMITH
, stealing 1 pair of boots, value 15s.; the goods of
Mark Wells.
MARK WELLS . I am a bombardier in the Royal Artillery at Woolwich—the prisoner was a private. About four o'clock, on 25th July, I missed these boots—I saw them safe at eight that moruing.
GEORGE WILLIAM WATERS . These boots were pawned with me by Mrs. Smith—I gave this duplicate for them—she said they were her husband's,
but he was dead, and directly afterwards she said they were her husband's boots that was to be.
CAROLINE SMITH . The prisoner gave me the boots to pawn, and said they were his own—I gave him the money and the ticket.

PETER ESARD . On 16th July I saw the prisoner and Smith at a public-house—the prisoner offered a duplicate of a pair of Wellington boots for sale for 1s. 6d.—I bought it, and gave it to Brown, to change it into my name.

GEORGE BROWN . I received this ticket, took it to the pawnbroker, and he stopped it—Smith followed me in, and said they were her boots, and then the prisoner ran in and said, "You are detaining my boots, are you? I will go and fetch the sergeant," and ran out.
Prisoner's Defence. Smith produced this ticket, and told roe to go and, sell it.

GUILTY . * Aged 23.—
Confined One Year.

2030.
EDWARD KELLY
, stealing 1 box, value 2s., and 841bs. weight of cocoa, the goods of the
London, Brighton, and South Coast Railway Company. (See page 858).

JOSHUA NUNN I am warehouseman to Francis Chambers and Henry Lambert, Tower Royal, Watling-street, cocoa-manufacturers. On 26th Jan. I sent a tea-chest with 3/4ewt. of cocoa to the Nag's Head to William Stone and Son, Newhaven, by the goods train, via Lewes—I was here at the trial of Garratt—I then saw a portion of the box which I had sent the cocoa in.

JAMES WOOD . I am warehouseman at the Nag's Head, Borough. On the evening of 26th Jan., a box was brought from Chambers and Lambert, directed to Stone and Son, Newhaven—I signed the deli very-book—next day it was sent to the New Cross station, to be sent by the railway.

GEORGE GROVES . I am in the service of the London, Brighton, and South Coast Railway. I was at work at the station between five and six o'clock—on 27th Jan. I saw Garratt there, who was afterwards tried in this Court—I saw a chest which had the appearance of a tea-chest amongst the goods on the railway—it was directed to Stone and Son, Newhaven—I saw Garratt handle the chest, and I saw him go off the platform—I did not see him take anything with him—I missed the chest, and gave information.

JAMES VOLLER . I am a porter at the New Cross station. About five o'clock, on 27th Jan., I remember a small cart coming with twenty-five tubs of butter—the prisoner drove it—he gave me a delivery-note for a larger num
ber of casks than he had brought, and he said his mate would be there shortly with the remainder—after the prisoner's cart was unloaded Garratt brought the remainder of the tubs of butter in a large cart—I signed the note and gave it to Garratt—the prisoner left the shed first.

JAMES CORRALL . I am one of the foremen of the Goods Department of the London, Brighton, and South Coast Railway. On the evening of 27th Jan., I received information from Green, and went in pursuit of two carts—Garratt drove the larger cart—I cannot say who drove the other—I went to the Lord Wellington, which is about a mile and a half from New Cross—I saw the two carts standing at the door—I jumped into the smaller cart, and found the chest covered with two tarpaulins and a mat—I found a part of the direction on it—the rest appeared to have been torn off—that was produced when Garratt was tried—there were no carmen with the carts when I got there; Chapman the ostler brought out Garratt—I waited a quarter of an hour to see it the driver of the smaller cart would come, but he was gone away.

WILLIAM CHAPMAN . I am ostler at the Lord Wellington. On the even
ing

of 27th Jan., there was a small cart came to our house—I do not know who was the driver of it—I never saw him before—he said he expected his mate with another cart—Garratt came up with a larger cart—I went out and saw them putting something out of the larger cart into the smaller one—I offered them assistance, and they said they did not want it—Mr. Corrall and another person came from the railway, and Garratt was given into custody—I did not sec the driver of the small cart again.

RICHARD OWEN . I am a carman, and live in the Commercial-road. The prisoner was in my employ—on 27th Jan., I sent him with some butter to the Railway station—Garratt was employed the same day to take the remain
der of the butter—the prisoner had a small cart—I saw it afterwards in the green-yard—Garratt had a much larger cart—after that day the prisoner did not return to my service—I owed him 11s.—he never came for it.

GEORGE HYDE (City-policeman, 516). On 17th July, I apprehended the prisoner, at a public-house in Whitecbapel-road—I told him the charge—he said he—was innocent, he did not know anything of it—I have known him two or three years—I saw him daily before Jan.—I have not seen him since this transaction.
NOT GUILTY .

2031.
JOHN DAVIS
, feloniously cutting and wounding
Joseph Plummer, with intent to do him grievous bodily harm.

JOSEPH PLUMMER . I live in Mill-lane, Deptford, and am a labouring man. The prisoner was a lodger in that house—on 17th July he came home in the afternoon—I was sitting in the kitchen with my wife—the prisoner began to use ill words, and said he had a little thing that would settle some one in the house—I did not answer him—he went out, and came back again be
tween nine and ten in the evening—he was not the worse for liquor—I believe he had taken something—I saw him strike a child who was there—I got up, and said, "If you hit him again, I shall hit you"—he said, "I am quite ready for you"—I struck him, he fell—he put the knife into me twice, and said, "Joe I have done it for you"—I found I was wounded in my right shoulder and breast, and my shirt was all blood—I was under the doctor for five weeks—the places are no: well now.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. What have you got your arm in a sling for? A. For the wound to close up—it is by the doctor's order—it has opened since this affair—the little boy, who is about twelve or thirteen, saw all that took place, I have not got him here—I have told all that took place—Mr. Longinotto, my landlord, was present—the prisoner came in and spoke to him—the prisoner sent for some beer, and asked me to partake of it soon after he came in—I did not meet the landlord and tell him I would stand it no longer, that I would knock his head off, or his brains out—the landlord told me it was not worth while to strike a drunken man—it was after that that I struck the prisoner, after he had hit the boy—when I struck the prisoner he fell down—I have not been complained of for being a very riotous, troublesome fellow—I have been before a Magistrate three or four times for being drunk—neither my landlord nor any one has complained of me that I know of.

SARAH PLUMMER . I am the prosecutor's wife. The prisoner came home in the middle of the day on 17th July—he said he had a little thing that he would settle one person in the house with that evening—he went out, and came in again between nine and ten o'clock—he began in the same way again, and he struck the boy—my husband said it was a shame to hit a

fatherless and motherless child, and if he did so again he would hit him—he slid, "You are the man I am waiting for "—they closed together, and my husband hit him and he fell—he said, "Joe, I have done for you "—I saw blood on my husband's shirt, and two wounds, one on the shoulder and one in the breast.
Cross-examined. Q. How does your husband get his living? A. He goes out hawking—I have been out with him—I have never been charged with begging.

HENRY HARRIS (policeman, R 232). On the evening of 17th July, I was fetched to the lodging-house in Mill-lane—I went into the house and could not see the prisoner—I went into the back yard—I heard some one run through the next house—I returned, and ran after the prisoner and caught him—I told him I wanted to take him for stabbing a man in the arm and breast—he said, "I am the man that did it, I will go"—I found on him this small knife in his waistcoat-pocket.

DAVID HOPE . I am a surgeon at Deptford. I saw the prosecutor on the evening of 17th July—I found a wound on the arm about three inches long, and two inches deep along the bone—he had been bleeding profusely—I suppose he had lost nearly three pints of blood—he was also bleeding from the right breast, where there was a wound about two inches and a half long, and half an inch deep—they appeared to me to be inflicted with a clasp-knife—I do not think this knife (produced) could have inflicted them—the wound on the arm was very dangerous—he was under my care some time, and is not yet recovered.

JOHN LONGINOTTO . I live in Mill-lane, Deptford. I am landlord of the prosecutor and the prisoner—on 17th July I recollect the prisoner being in the kitchen—he asked me to have some beer—he then offered it to my wife, and then to the prosecutor—the prosecutor said, "No, I want no beer from you, if I want beer I can pay for it"—I went out, and as I came in I met the prosecutor—he said, "I will stand it no longer to please anybody "—I said, "It is not worth while to strike a drunken man, you may as well strike a child "—we then went in—I said to the prisoner, "Let me sit down "—he got up, and the prosecutor directly knocked him down without the least pro
vocation—the prosecutor said, "I am stabbed, I am stabbed! "—I did not see anything in the prisoner's band—if there had been a clasp knife I must have seen it.
COURT. Q. Did you stab him? A. No—I did not see anybody stab him.

Cross-examined. Q. You were there just before this took place? Yes, after the prosecutor struck the prisoner—I did not see the prisoner strike him—I do not recollect hearing him say, "Joe, I have done for you"—all the place was in an uproar—I heard a good many words—I was sober—I never drink anything—there was a child there—I heard them say be struck him—he must have struck him while I was in the yard—as I was coming in I met the prosecutor in the wash-house.

GUILTY . Aged 29.—
Transported for Seven Years.

2032.
SOLOMON JOHN LOVELL
, stealing 1 hammer, and other tools, value 4s. 4d.; the goods of
John Penn and others, his masters; to which he pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 50.—
Confined One Month .

2033.
ELIZABETH PATTISON
. stealing 2 sheets, value 3s.; the goods of
William Dufton.

ANN DUFTON . I am the wife of William Dufton, of Woolwich. The pri
soner came to lodge with me—she left—I missed two sheets—I saw her
again, and charged her—she said she would give me the duplicate and the 2s.—I went to the pawnbroker's, and found them.
Prisoner. I told you 1 was coming back next day, and would settle everything.

Prisoner's Defence (written). "I lived with my prosecutor eight weeks along with my husband; I went to see my friends at Chatham; I left my husband in the room; a week after I was gone, and he then absconded; on Monday, the prosecutor came to Chatham to me, and told me my husband was gone, and that they had missed their sheets; I told them that I was coming home in a day or two, and that I would settle everything; they told rne they did not wish to hurt me; we went out together, and when we re
turned, her husband had got the man to take me in charge; I was taken to Woolwich, and the Magistrate heard my case; he fined me 10s., and in de
fault of payment, I was to go seven days to Maidstone; I was brought back again in twenty minutes, and told that my prosecutor was not satisfied, they wanted their expenses; and the man that took me was not a Metropolitan policeman; the Magistrate said he could not pay them their expenses; they then sent me for trial, to see if they would get them here; I have been in confinement seven weeks; I hope you will have mercy upon me, as it is my first time of being in prison, and it will be for ever a warning to me."
NOT GUILTY .

2034.
JAMES CAREY
, stealing 1 half-crown, the money of
John Bayley, his master.

RICHARD BAYLEY . I live at Woolwich, with my brother John, who keeps a grocer's shop—he had lost money—the prisoner was in his service. On 9th Aug. I marked a half-crown and a five-shilling-piece, and six shillings were marked and put in the till in my presence—after my brother was gone to London I placed the half-crown in the till—it was the only half-crown there—the prisoner came in ten minutes—he went to the part where the till was—I then went to the till, and the half-crown was gone—I followed the prisoner, who had then left to go to the Arsenal, and charged him with having stolen the half-crown—he said he had not—I told him to produce the money he had in his pocket—he produced a sixpence, some copper, and this half-crown—my brother returned, and gave him into custody.

Cross-examined by MR. COOK EVANS. Q. Has he been out of custody since he was taken? A. Yes—we preferred another charge against him, about a half-crown—I saw him when he was out of custody close to our house—he was in our shop about twenty minutes on the day this half-crown was stolen—this is the half-crown—these are the marks I made on it—I did not mark other money.
WILLIAM GLADWIN (policeman, R 122). I received this half-crown from the inspector—the policeman who received it is dead.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Confined Nine Months.

2035.
THOMAS FOREST
, feloniously breaking and entering the counting-house of
George Moore, and stealing a telescope, value. 2l. 2s., and 1d., his property; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .** Aged 17.—
confined Nine Months.
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

2036.
ROBERT PARROTT
, stealing one pair of boots, value 25s.; the goods of
Henry Isaac Brewer.

HENRY ISAAC BREWER . I conduct the business of a public-house at Rotherhithe, for my mother-in-law. On 14th Aug. the prisoner was there—I missed these boots from the kitchen, and met him leaving the house—I said, "What have you done with, the boots you took from here?"—he said, "I have no boots "—his apron was pulled down, and the boots were under it—I save him in charge.

HENRY NEWBERRY . I saw the prisoner come from the passage with a boot protruding from his jacket—I found a pair of boots under his apron—he said they were given to him—at the station he threatened to serve me out when he got his liberty.
Prisoner's Defence. There was a row there, and a man asked me to take care of them.

GUILTY . Aged 37.—
Confined Six Months.

2037.
JOHN LAWRENCE , and
HENRY CHAPPEL
, stealing 100 sovereigns, 80 half-crowns, 500 shillings, 200 sixpences, and 2 bags, value 2d.; the goods of
Edward Smith, (since deceased,) in his dwelling-house.

EDWARD SMITH . I live with my mother, at the Bricklayers' Arms, Eccleston-street, Pimlico. My father died last Dec.—he was alive at the time of this robbery, but it hastened his death—on 15th Sept. last, about a quarter-past four o'clock in the afternoon, I was in Eccleston-street, near our house, and the two prisoners came up to me, and asked if I could tell them where the Bricklayers' Arms was—I do not think they mentioned the land
lord's name—I directed them—I went home half an hour after, and they were then standing at the bar, drinking gin and water—on 21st Sept., about seven in the evening, I saw both the prisoners again—I saw Lawrence first in company with another man, not Chappel—they were standing at the counter, taking half-and-half—Chappel came in shortly afterwards, and called for a glass of half-and-half—he stood talking to me about a quarter of an hour—after that Lawrence and his companion asked for two glasses of gin—Chappel was not with them—I had to turn my back to serve the gin, and when I turned round again Chappel was gone—I did not see him go—Law
rence and his companion had some gin and cigars—they then began to talk about their friend not having come; that they should not stop any longer, and they left shortly after—soon after that, my sister Mary, who was sitting sewing, jumped up, and ran up stairs, as though something had suddenly attracted her attention—she then called out to me that the house had been robbed.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Is yours a corner house? A. Yes; the wall of the skittle-ground is about ten feet high—there is a back door—there is no field at the back—the skittle-ground is covered in—there is a street at the other side of the wall—a person would have to get over a wall twelve feet high to get in at the back-door—that door is kept locked, and my father and the man were in the skittle-ground, making a new skittle-frame.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. When did you see Chappel again? A. About six weeks ago, at the Police-court—there were two other people sitting in the tap-room on the 21st; that was all the company in the house at that time—I had been in the house all day—I did not go out till this alarm.
MARY ANN M'CLARY . I am sister of the last witness—I have been married since I made my deposition. On 21st Sept., about seven o'clock, I was

sitting in the bar-parlour, at work—there are some stairs that lead up to the sleeping apartments, across the passage, facing the bar-parlour door—I remember seeing Lawrence at the bar—I heard two men talking at the bar, and another one talking to my brother, and all at once I thought I heard a step at the bottom of the stairs, going from the stairs to the tap-room door; push the tap-room door open instantly which makes a noise, let it go, and go very quickly across the passage, out at the front door—I jumped up, went into the bar, took up a candlestick, and I saw Lawrence and another man. standing at the bar—Chappel was not the second man—I went up stairs, and as I went up Lawrence and the other man went out at the front door—I found my mother's bed-room door standing open—it had been locked, and I had seen the key in the till a quarter of an hour before, and it was there when I went down again—I smelt a smell of lucifer-matches, went in, and found the closet-door standing open, which was always kept locked, and my mother had the key in her pocket—I instantly ran down stairs, and gave the alarm that the bed-room and cupboard doors had been broken open, and the money gone—the money had been in the closet in my mother's bed-room—I had seen it safe in the afternoon—there was a hundred sovereigns in one bag, and 40l. in silver in the other—the closet-door appeared to have been forced open by some small instrument; the screws—were forced off the lock—there was the mark of the instrument in two places—the room-door appeared to have been opened by picking the lock; there was no appearance of violence—I had seen my mother lock the cupboard-door, between two and three that afternoon, and put the key in her pocket—she then locked the bedroom-door, brought the key down stairs, and put it in the till.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Had you ever seen the prisoners before? A. Yes, on the previous Saturday.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON.Q. Had you counted the money? A. Yes, the 40l. worth of silver, on the Monday afternoon—I saw the bags of money on the Tuesday afternoon, in the same position as they had been the day before, apparently undisturbed—I saw these three persons before I went up stairs—they were all gone when I came down—I did not myself see Chappel at all that night—I had been serving at the bar—I had not been silting down above half an hour—my brother was then serving—he had been at home the whole time—I heard only one footstep, like one person stepping on the bottom step of the stairs—it was just one single movement.

EDWARD SMITH
re-examined. There were two regular customers in the tap-room, at seven o'clock; men that I know—they went out with me in pursuit of the men—they have used the house for years, and have been there since.
JURY. Q. Have you any reason to believe that any person about there knew where your mother kept the money? A. Yes, but I cannot bring that home.
NOT GUILTY .

2038.
JOHN LAWRENCE and
HENRY CHAPPEL were again in
dicted for
stealing 1 purse, value 6d., and 10 sovereigns; the moneys of
James Wood, in his dwelling-house.

MART WOOD . I am the wife of James Wood, of 16 1/2, Manor-place, Wal
worth—we keep a retail beer-shop. On Tuesday, 5th Oct. last, about eight o'clock in the evening, I deposited some money in a box, and left it on the mantel-piece, in my bed-room, on the first-floor—I shut the door but did not lock it—after that I came down to the bar-parlour, which is behind the bar—about nine the two prisoners came in, and two others with them, and went

into the parlour—no one could come into the bar, or the parlour, without my seeing them—a person must pass the stairs to get to the parlour-door—the stairs are about a yard or a yard and a half from the bar—they had some ale, and tobacco and pipes, and I believe some cigars—they staid about half an hour, and all four went away together—I went into the parlour while they were there, and Chappel went out—he said he was ill—I had left the parlour when they came in, and went into the bar—I heard, from my daughter, that one of them was ill—she was to and fro, waiting on them—I did not see him go out—he could not have gone out at the front door without my seeing him—while I was in the bar no one passed the bar towards the stairs from nine till eleven but those four people—several customers had come to the bar—none of them went beyond the bar—I was not away between eight and eleven—if anybody had come in from the front door, and gone to the stairs within that time, I must have seen them—no one but those four came from nine till eleven—we shut up at eleven, and went to bed, and then found the box broken open, and the money gone—my husband bad also been in the bar—the bar does not command a view of the stairs—a person might have stepped out of the parlour, and gone up stairs without being observed—there is no door at the foot of the stairs—the bar opens into a little passage, in which the stairs are.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Which way. do you turn to go into the parlour? A. You must go into the passage, and pass the stairs leading to the bed-room—the parlour is beyond the stairs, and the bar is on this side of them—there is a back door that leads into the garden—there is no com
munication with any other premises—the back door is shut, it was not fastened, we always keep it shut—the bar commands a view of the passage—I think a person could not slip in at—the back door while my back was turned—I should hear a step coming in that way—I might not bear them if they came in stealthily.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. Would you not be just as likely to hear a step on the stairs? A. It would depend on bow a person went up—it is almost an impossibility for anybody to come in the back way—I was not in the parlour when Chappel left—he could have gone out at the back door—he did not come out the front way—all four went away together after he had returned—he was only out a short time—there is a watering place at the back door—I last saw the money safe at eight o'clock—the pri
soners were there half an hour—it is impossible to say how many people were there at the same time, there were several coming for supper beer—I do not swear distinctly to Chappel—I can to Lawrence.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. How is the garden surrounded?A. By a pailing—it is a row of houses—there are houses and gardens both sides of us—there is no opening into a street or lane—there are not houses at the back—the pailings are half as high as your head—if a person got over our pailing he would get into the adjoining garden, and that leads to another house—the back door was fastened with two bolts and a latch—if the latch had been lifted I do not know that I should have heard it in the bar—there is a sum
mer-house at the bottom of the garden, and a hedge behind that—if a person got over there he would come into other people's gardens, not into a lane.

JANE WOOD . I am the daughter of the last witness, and live with her. I remember the prisoners and two others coming on 5th Oct.—they went iuto the parlour—Lawrence ordered four glasses of ale, and afterwards he ordered 1d. worth of tobacco and some pipes, which I took in—he said he did not wish for 1d. worth of tobacco, but a pipe of tobacco—I took that in, then

one who is not here asked for a cigar—I should say I was sent out of the room four or five times, first for one thing, and then for another—when I took the cigars in I noticed that Chappel had left the room—I remained in the room till he returned—he was away about five or seven minutes—he complained to his companions of being ill—he said he could not stop, nor yet drink his ale—the other three drank their ale, and they then all left together—I never went anywhere the whole of that evening, except from the parlour to the bar—from eight o'clock to the time of shutting up no one had come in at the front, and gone up stairs; only these four had passed the stairs—they were the only persons who had the opportunity.

Cross-examined hy MR. PAYNE. Q. About how many people came for beer for supper? A. A great many—the person who stood in the bar served them as they came to the front of the bar—none, except these four used the parlour that evening.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. As soon as you got into the room you were sent out again for something? A. Yes—I was there hardly a minute—Chappel did not send me for anything—I went about my business when not there—I did not see Chappel again till J saw him at the Police-court, in the dock with Laurence—I pointed him out as the man—I do not think thev were in the room at all without my father or mother being there the greater part of the time—if one was not there the other was.

JAMES WOOD . I was at home on the evening of 5th Oct., when the four men came in—I missed Chappel on one occasion—I believe him to be the man, but I would not swear to him—I was in the parlour when he came back; he complained of being poorly, and he said he could not stay, and they all four went away together—when we went to bed we found that the box was broken—a piece of candle and a Jucifer-match were afterwards shown me and I saw a mark on the wall where the match had been struck to light it—next morning I saw my wife find another lucifer-match under the chair where Chappel had sat—there is gas in the parlour by which persons could light a pipe—that would not be alight in the day time—it would be impossible for a person to get to the stairs without coming through the bar, except they came out of the parlour—I must have seen any one coming in at the front door, even if they crept down under the counter—it is a square room, with a passage parted off.

MRS. WOOD re-examined. I found a lucifer-match next morning in sweep
ing up the parlour, under the chair where Chappel had sat, it was exactly like the one the policeman had found on the stairs—they were common matches—no one was smoking in the room that night—I destroyed the match.

WILLIAM MORRIS (policeman, P 29). I was called to the prosecutor's house on 5th Oct., and on the landing of the first-floor stairs, about a yard from Mrs. Wood's bed-room door, I found about two inches of composition candle—I also found a lucifer-match about three inches from the candle—it had been ignited—I noticed a mark on the wall where it had been apparently lighted—this house was formerly a private house—when you go in you face the bar, it is an open room, but there is a place which you may term a pas
sage, leading to the stairs, about two feet after you had passed the counter, and there is a back door there—I do not think a person could pass from the front door to the stairs without being seen—the counter is about four feet high, and the place where the beer is drawu is upon it, but that would not prevent a person being seen.

LAWRENCE—
GUILTY . Aged 28.

CHAPPEL—
GUILTY . Aged 23.
(There were two other indictments against the prisoners.)

2039.
GEORGE PEARSON
, for feloaiously being at large before the ex
piration of the term for which he had been transported.

JOHN WADE . I am steward at the convict establishment at Portsmouth—I know the prisoner, and recollect his being on board the hulks there—he escaped on 3rd April—he had been sentenced to twenty years transportation, from this Court.
THOMAS WATKINS (policeman, M 18.) I was present in this Court in Nov., 1846, when the prisoner was sentenced to be transported for twenty years—I am quite sure he is the person.
Prisoner. Q. Did you have me? A. Yes, it was for robbing a lady of 1l. 18s.

WILLIAM DERRIG (policeman). I took the prisoner in July, in a public-house, in Mint-street—he resisted most violently with an open clasp-knife—I charged him with being a returned transport—he said, he was transported innocent, and it was his intention to do for one of us—another officer was assisting me.

GUILTY . Aged 28.—
Transported for Life .

2040.
CHARLES M'PHERSON
, feloniously wounding
Henry Decimus Ilderton, with intent to do him grievous bodily harm.

HENRY DECIMUS ILDERTON . I am a solicitor, and live at Grove-cottage, St. James's-street, Old Kent-road. On 15th Aug. I was angling in the Surrey Canal—the prisoner and three or four other boys were on the canal in boats—he was alone in a boat, and was splashing about the water with his oars, evidently to annoy those who were fishing—we asked him and the others to go away—after some time they did so, but came back again—the prisoner broke the top of my fishing-rod—I jumped into his boat and gave him a slap over the head—he jumped ashore and said, "I will serve you out for this"—he got hold of the rope and began dragging the boat along the canal wilh me in it—he picked up a stone—I jumped out of the boat and ran after him to make him give it up, and just as I got up to him his father got out of a barge and came up to me with his fists up to strike me—the prisoner stumbled over a dog and fell—the father came up in an attitude to strike me, and just at that moment I received a severe blow from a stone on the right temple—it must have come from the prisoner who was on my right side—I bled very much—my hat was cut through the brimlining, and all—with the assistance of one of the bargemen I went to a surgeon, and was under his care for a week.
Prisoner. He knocked me down and took away the sculls from me. Witness. A. I did not—I merely gave him a slight cuff over the head, such as you would give a schoolboy.

EDWARD JACKMAN . I was anglingin the canal—the boys were annoying me by frightening away the fish—I did not see Mr. Ilderton get into the boat, but hearing a laugh among the men I turned round, and saw him in it, and the prisoner pulling him along—I saw him pick up part of a brick—Mr. Ilderton ran after him—the father ran up to strike him—the boy fell, got up again, and after dodging about two or three times I saw him throw a brick, which struck Mr. Ilderton on the temple—he was only about four yards off at the time.
RICHARD WILLIAM KEY (policeman, R 339). I took the prisoner, and told him it was for throwing a stone at a gentleman—he said he had nothing to say to it—he could not deny it.

JOHN ANDERSON . I am a surgeon. I attended Mr. Ilderton—he had a wound on the right temple, rather more than an inch long, and completely dividing the scalp down to the bone—it bled largely—it was of a dangerous character, but is now healing.

GUILTY of an Assault. Aged 11.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury and Prosecutor.—
Confined One Month

2041.
MARY ANN STAPLES
, breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Richard Eldridge, and stealing 2 half-crowns, 3s., and 5 sixpences; his moneys.

RICHARD ELDRIDGE . I live in Alfred-place, Battersea. On 22nd Aug., at twenty-five minutes before five in the morning, I left my room to go to work, leaving in the table-drawer two bags containing the money stated—I double locked the door—I returned about eight in the evening, and my money was gone, also some bread and butter and sugar—I have known the prisoner from her infancy—she was born in the same yard, but was never in my room—one of my half-crowns had a mark on it by which I know it—this is it (produced)—I told the policeman the mark that was on it before I ex
amined it (pointing out the mark)—the staple of the door had been forced away, as if by a chisel.

MARY ANN BIRD . The prisoner lodged with me on Friday evening last—she only slept there one night—it was out of charity—this chisel (produced) is my husband's—it was kept in a drawer—the prisoner might have taken it without my knowing it while I was out at work.
THOMAS DAVIS (policeman). I examined the door—there were marks of violence which appear to have been made with this chisel, which was brought to me from a drawer by Mrs. Bird.

MRS. BIRD re-examined. My husband was in the country on this oc
casion—another young woman lodged in the house, but she was at Wands
worth then—only me and the prisoner were at home—I did not break open the door.

JOHN LAW . I am a linen-draper. The prisoner bought some things of me, and paid me with two half-crowns—I put them in the till with the rest—inquiry was made of me next morning—I produced all the money I had in the till—there were three half-crowns—this produced is one of them—I cannot say how many I might have received that day—I know I gave change for gold.
JOHN WALLIS (policeman). I took the prisoner and told her she was charged with this—she said she knew nothing about it.
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Baron Plait.

2042.
JAMES DOWLING
feloniously blabbing
James Scott, with intent to do him some grevious bodily harm.

JAMES SCOTT . I live in High-street, Shadwell. On 18th July, I was in front of the Red Lion, Deptford-road, drinking with other people—I went into the back yard to make water, and saw the prisoner sitting with two females—in a minute or two a stone struck me on the head, I did not see who threw it—I was at a regular place, out of thefemales' sight—I went up to the prisoner and asked him what he did it for—he said, "I meant to pitch the stone into the second butt"—I said, "It is very strange you should throw it at me when I am a stranger"—I spoke quietly—he said, "If you don't like it you can have more of it," and wanted to fight—he made a blow at me—we had two rounds, and both fell—he pulled out a knife, opened it, showed it to me and said, "I will give you this"—an officer came and made him shut it up—

said, "Then, b----your eyes, I won't go," and bit me in the eye—Mitchell he put it into his pocket for a minute or two, and then pulled it out, and wanted to fight again—we had another round, with the knife shut in his hand—I knocked him down—we got up again—I was rather enraged, and knocked him down again—he got up on his knees, opened the knife, and stabbed me in the lower part of my belly—I went down the street, but could not find a doctor—I felt the blood trickling down—some one put me into a cart, and took me to the hospital—I was there nine days, and continued an out patient afterwards.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. How many times did you knock him down? A. Twice, it was not three times—he said he was too weak a man to fight with me, and be must stab me if I attempted to strike him again, but he had given the first offence—he only said so once, and I did not strike him after—he called on the police to protect him—he said I had assaulted him, and the policeman said he would take him if he did not shut the knife up—we had four rounds, each terminated in his being knocked down—I was recognised at the hospital as a person to be charged with an assault—a warrant was taken out against me on the day this happened—I have been before the Magistrate for it, and my friends paid 5l. fine for me.

COURT. Q. Did the prisoner tell the policeman he armed himself with a knife to protect himself? A. No—when he threatened to stab me, I said, "If you do I will knock you down"—there were two females telling him to go on—he stabbed me, and said, "There you are."

JOSEPH TAYLOR . I am an iron-moulder, of Duke's-place. I was at the side of the public-house, heard a noise, went into the back-yard, and saw Scott: knock the prisoner down—he got up, and had some severe words—Scott pitched into him again—they both fell, kicking each other—Scott went outside the gate, and then came back, and began abusing the prisoner—they came to high words—the prisoner said if he struck him again he would use his knife—it was in his hand, closed—a policeman came—the prisoner said, "You are a policeman, do your duty," and gave Scott in charge—the police
man said, "If I do my duty, I shall take you, for having a knife," and parted them, and went away—Scott turned back, and said, "Do you dare to take out a knife to me?"—he said, "I do not want to fight you, I am not able to fight you"—Scott knocked him down two or three rimes, and went towards him as he laid on the ground, and was going to strike him while down, and the prisoner put the knife into him—I consider he did it in his own defence.
NOT GUILTY .

2043.
GEORGE BAKER
, feloniously assaulting
George Bird, and wound
ing him on the forehead, with intent to resist his lawful apprehension.

JOHN POTTER (policeman, V 118). On Sunday, 6th Aug., I was on duty in Battersea Fields—there was a fair there—I saw the prisoner there with a convicted thief—they went behind a gentleman, and he put his hand to the bottom of his pocket, but got nothing there, they then went up to where there was a weighing-machine, and a number of people round it—the prisoner put his hand into Bird's pocket, and took out this handkerchief (produced)—I said, "Have you lost anything?"—he put his hand into bis pocket, and said, "I have lost my handkerchief"—I took the prisoner—he had one corner of the hand
kerchief in his hand—Bird claimed it, and went with us—on the way to the station we went along a bank in the fields, twelve or fourteen feet high—the prisoner said to Bird, "Pray, let me go"—he said, "No"—the prisoner

came to my assistance—the prisoner knocked him down, very nearly into the Thames—I and Bird caught hold of the prisoner—we struggled against the fence—he endeavoured to get us towards the Thames—he struck me several times in the face, and caught me in the privates—he said, "B----your eyes, I will give it you"—three or four times over he said if I would let him get up he would go quietly—I did so—he struck me again—I saw a soldier while I was struggling, named George Bird, the brother of the other man—I called him to my assistance—he came—we all three went down together—the pri
soner was undermost—he said to George Bird, "B----your eyes, I will do something for you," or something to that effect, and threw this brick at him (produced), and cut him over the eye with it—there was a heap of bricks—he laid with his side against them—Tupney came to our assistance—we got the prisoner to the station.

Prisoner. Q. Was any one near me? A. About twenty people—one was a convicted thief, named Scott—I did not say I could make a good job of it now, and I could give you three months—I did not take the handker
chief off the ground—I was in plain clothes—I did not pull your handkerchief till you were black in the face, or kick your head—the blood on you was from Bird's forehead.

CHARLES BIRD . I am a labourer, of 37, Milton-street, Vincent-square. I was at Battersea Fields, by a weighing-machine—Potter showed me'a hand
kerchief, which I identified—he took the prisoner—I went with them—he resisted by the river—my brother came to my assistance, and the prisoner gave him a blow on the forehead with a brick.

GEORGE BIRD . I am a private in the first batalion of Grenadier Guards. I was at Battersea Fields, and saw the struggle—Potter asked me to assist—I took hold of the prisoner by his collar and handkerchief—he got up and made a rush at Potter to strike him—there was a scuffle, and he fell on a heap of bricks—Potter allowed him to get up—the prisoner rushed at him again—we got him down—he threw one or two bricks—the last one struck me on the forehead—I was quite senseless for several minutes—the skin was broken—it bled a great deal—I went to the hospital, and am not yet well.

WILLIAM OWEN TUPNEY (policeman, V 48). I was on duty—a gentle
man spoke to me—I went, and saw the prisoner scuffling with Potter—George Bird was bleeding furiously—I laid hold of the prisoner—he said, "If you had not come up when you had, I should have split the whole five b----skulls, and then I should have got away"—there was a mob—I took him to the station.

FRANCIS CORNELIUS HUTHWAITE . I am surgeon to Bird's regiment. I examined his head—he had a contused wound on the forehead—the skin was broken—this brick would have done it—he is still in the hospital—any blunt body thrown with violence would cause a similar wound, but it would require violence.

Prisoner's Defence. The handkerchief was across my legs; I knew nothing about it; the policeman put his knuckles into my neck, and I struck him; he struck me, knocked me down, and knelt on me; the prosecutor struck me several times; I was bruised all over.

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Transported for Ten Years.

2044.
GEORGE SHELL
, unlawfully making a certain seditious speech and for attending an unlawful assembly.
MR. ATTORNEY-GENERAL, with MESSRS. WELSBY, BODKIN, and CLERK conducted the Prosecution.

WIILIAM COUNSELL . I live at Camberwell, and am a short-hand writer—on the evening of Friday, 28th July, I was present at a meeting at the Chartist Hall, Webber-street, Blackfriars'-road—I got there shortly before eight o'clock—I should say there were from 150 to 200 people present—the number increased afterwards to about 500—they appeared to be working men—a person named Bryson was elected chairman—I heard the defendant speak there—three persons had spoken before him, one was a person of the name of Keene—I took a short-hand note of Shell's speech—this is it—(reads—"Mr. Chairman and fellow-workingmen—Being called upon to come forward and propose the second resolution to be submitted to your notice this evening, I do so with feelings of great pleasure and satisfaction, because the opportunity which now presents itself leads me to embrace that opportunity for the pur
pose of expressing my opinion as to what I consider to be the policy of the English Government towards that unfortunate country, Ireland, as well as to express my determination and disapprobation of the same. The resolution I submit to you is as follows:—'Resolved, that this meeting do solemnly protest against the base and unconstitutional act of the British Legislature, as committed by them in the suspending of the Habeas Corpus Act in Ireland; and further, do hereby tender to Feargus O'Connor, Esq., Member of Parliament, and to those gentlemen who supported him, our best thanks for their manly and patriotic conduct on that occasion; and further, that we do hereby solemnly pledge ourselves, that we will render in the hour of trial our full aid and co-operation to our Irish brethren.' In making a few remarks upon the resolution I have submitted to you, you will at once perceive that the resolution which I have moved may fairly be divided into three points; first, condemnation; secondly, commendation; and thirdly, de
termination. In reference to the act of the Legislature in suspending the Habeas Corpus Act in Ireland, it may-perhaps be necessary, for a few moments, that we take a retrospective view of the proceedings of that Legis
lature in connection with Irish affairs. If we look back to history, and trace the proceedings from the time of the Union up to the present, we shall find that the policy of the English Government towards that unhappy country has been one systematic system of coercion. The Irish people at the time of the Union were promised equality with the English people; they were promised that they should have equal laws and equal justice with the English people. Now, Mr. Chairman, although I have not condemned the acts of the Legislature in connection with my own country, I have still to condemn, and more justly too, I think, the acts of the Legislature in connection with Ireland, whenever and by whomsoever an appeal has been made to the Legislature of this country for justice to the Irish people, it has always been met by a system of coercion entirely; the English people have been coerced as well, and more especially of late, than they formerly were. You will remember that the English people, as well as the Irish people, have wrongs which they justly complain of, and they complain most reasonably and most justly too, because, as men and Englishmen, and as the wealth-producers of this country, they consider they have a right to a fair repre
sentation in the House of Commons, which at present they are denied. Such is the case with Ireland; and until, as my friend who moved the first resolution observed, Ireland is fairly represented by the people and for the people, no good will ever accrue either to the one country or the other. We know, Mr. Chairman, that there have been fine spirits of late exhibited in the sister country, as well as in this country; men have sprung up who have declared to the people, and told them and taught them what they are as men,

what they should be as men, and how they may obtain that which they seek Mitchell, the Irish patriot, who has been condemned and transported as a felon for freely explaining to the Irish people what was their duty, what were their rights, and how they were to obtain them, has been sacrificed and made the victim, for promulgating those principles which I am quite glad to see at present are so prominent among the Irish people. Ireland has been taught by the Apostle Mitchell, and I rejoice to see that, although the Govern
ment has removed him, there are other individuals equally as patriotic as himself, who have nobly and manfully come forward and taken the people by the hand, and declared that they will to the death lead them on, if possible, to victory. Mr. Chairman, I rejoice that such has been the case; and I recommend to the Irish people to follow implicitly the commands of their leaders. I would call also upon the English people who desire liberty, who desire justice, and who desire equality, to stand by the Irish people in the hour of need. As soon as the Irish people are up, as soon as the insur
rection in Ireland becomes general, (as I believe in the course of a very few hours it will become general), I trust that the people of England will rise to support them. Mr. Chairman and fellow working men, for whatever I say I care not, whatever may follow, I as an Englishman consider that on all occasions, and upon every occasion, when my conscience dictates to me that I have an opportunity of speaking to my fellow men in public or in private, I have an unbounded right to tell them what is the honest conviction of my mind; and if I suffer for so doing, I shall only be another added to the band of patriots who have been crushed; and if, working men, you do allow those men who do nobly come forward and tell you your rights, and how to obtain them, if you allow them to be picked away, if you allow them to be trans
ported, to enjoy, I was going to say, but rather to be placed in a dungeon, there to suffer all the indignities which it is possible for a base, bloody, and brutal Government to inflict, you do not deserve the name of men, but you ought to be incarcerated yourselves, your families ought to starve around you, and you ought to go howling through the streets as a base and cowardly race of men. Gentlemen, I am not inclined to take up much of your time this evening. In what I say, however humble it may be, remember I am only a working man, and have not much time to spare to study to make use of fine grammatical expressions. I sincerely and honestly co-operate with the friends of liberty as much as those who have more time to spare and to devote to the cause. But, gentlemen, allow me to ask you if you are men, will ye act as men? (cries of "Yes.") If ye are called on to-night, to-morrow, or at any other time, do not show you are cowards, and flinch, but rally round the standard of liberty, defend it with your lives, and may God Almighty grant we may be victorious, that our enemies may be crushed, that they may hide their heads in the dungeons in the hulks, and that our honest patriots may be restored to us, and that they may take their places is my sincere wish."

Q. In what manner was this speech received by the meeting? A. With applause at various parts of it—the resolution Mr. Keene moved was as follows:—"Resolved, that this meeting views with feelings of distrust and alarm the measure adopted by her Majesty's Government, and sanctioned by the Imperial Parliament, for the suppression of public opinion in Ireland, as tending to the final severance of all amicable relations between the two countries; and this meeting is further of opinion, that the Irish people are fully entitled to a free and independent Parliament, and therefore resolves to render to their patriotic brethren in Ireland their cordial sympathy."

before the defendant spoke he was introduced by the chairman in the meeting as the secretary—after Shell's speech, some Irish, a deputation of the Mitchell Club, came in—I think Shell was there then, but I cannot be positive.
Prisoner. Q. When I said, "If you are men, will you act as men?" will you swear positively the answer gicen was "Yes?" A. Yes, I have it "yes" put down at the time.
Court. Q. Did you observe whether the prisoner read the resolution, or gave it? A. It was read as if it had been previously prepared.

WILLIAM HENRY MAINWARING (policeman, L 86). I apprehended the prisoner on 2nd Aug. on a warrant, as he was coming out of the Chartist meeting in Webber-street—I afterwards went to where he lived, No. 2, Princes-place, Princes-street, London-road, and found this book and paper (produced) there—I took them from a room pointed out to me by Mr. Lord.

GEORGE LORD. I live at 2, Princes-place, London-road—the defendant rented a room there—when Mainwaring came there on 2nd Aug. I accom
panied him to the room where the defendant lodged, and there saw him find the book and paper produced—(read—"Mr. Side, I am instructed to request the favour of your attendance at a meeting of the London secretaries, to be held on Sunday morning, at ten o'clock; be prepared to report the num
ber of the enrolled members, and the general state of the district. Signed, on behalf of the Executive, L. M. Kid, John-street Institution, July 25, 1848. Make the bill enclosed public as possible."—" John-street, July 25, 1848,—Mr. Charles Keene,—I am instructed to request you to be present at the meeting of the London secretaries, to be held in the Assembly-rooms, Dean-street on Sunday next, at ten o'clock, a.m. Be prepared to report on the state of the district, and give a return of the enrolled members, &c. Signed, on behalf of the Executive, SAML. KIDD. ")—in the book was written in pencil, "Proposed by Mr. Cufiy,—That each district send four men to Cartwright's, to arrange a plan of communication."

MR. RICHARD KEMMIS . I produce from the office of the Clerk of the Crown of Dublin a copy of the record of he conviction of John Mitchell—I examined it with the original—it is correct—The Attorney-General here stated that the indictment against Mitchell was for printing and publishing certain arti
cles in the "United Irishman," and read the following passages,—" Mob law itself in Ireland is far better than Government law; that well-ordered and civilized system, that slays its millions of human beings within the year. I tell you, that rather than endure one other year of British domination, I would take a provisional government, selected out of the men that are bellow
ing out there in the streets" (loud cheers)—"Or can I condemn the alterna
tive put by Mr. Meagher, who says, 'When the last constitutional appeal shall be made, and shall fail, then up with the barricades, and invoke the God of battles.' Can I repudiate this, who bold that constitutional appeals are long since closed against us, and that we have even now no resource, except when we have the means and the pluck to do it. The barricades and the God of battles' No; all the seditions and treasons of these gentlemen I adopt and accept, and I ask for more. Whatever has been done or said by the most disaffected persons in all Ireland against the existence of the party which calls itself the Government, nothing can go too far for me. Whatever public treasons there are in this land, I have stomach for them all.'—"But while we meet the enemy in the Queen's Bench, we have a right to call upon you to sustain us by a firm and universal avowal of your opinion—upon the

constituents of Smith O'Brien especially devolves this duty—while the British Parliament calls his exertions treason and felony, it is for his constituents to declare, that in all this treason and felony he is doing his duty by them; and more than this, it is your duty to prepare systematically to sustain him, if it come to that, in arms. May I presume to address the women of Limerick? It is the first time I have ever been in the presence of the daughters of those heroines who held the breach against King "William; and they will under
stand me when I say, that no Irishwoman ought so much as to speak to a man who has not provided himself with arms. No lady is too delicate for the culinary operation of casting bullets; no hand is too white to make up cartridges; and I hope, if it be needful to come to the last resort, that the citizens of Limerick, male and female, will not disgrace their paternal and maternal ancestors"——"Now the fact is, the editor of the United Irishman, " meaning Mr. Mitchell, "is no hero at all, and never said he was: he has only endeavoured to persuade his countrymen that they will never gain their liberties except by fighting for them; and that the only arguments the British Government will understand are the points of pikes, that's all; and he con
tinues to preach this saving doctrine, and will continue so to do, until a considerable number of his countrymen agree with him, and then he hopes to aid in enforcing the arguments practically, that's all. As for the sneaking away of Mr. Mitchell, or Mr. Meagher, or any of them, under the protection of the police, it is merely an untruth; the writer in the Times who wrote it, and the editor of Saunders and the Mail, who we find have copied it, know it to be an untruth."——"How are we to meet that day? In arms, my countrymen, in arms! Thus, and not otherwise, have ever nations of men sprung to liberty and power: but why do I reason thus with you, Irishmen cf Ulster, who never have denied the noble creed and sentiment of manhood? You have not been schooled for forty years in the fatal cant of moral force; you have not been utterly debauched and emasculated by the clap-trap platiudes of public meetings, and the empty glare of imposing demonstrations. You have not yet learned the litany of slaves, and the whine of beaten hounds, and the way to die a coward's death. No; let once the great day of your country's destiny seize on you my townsmen, and the way will be as plain before you as a pike-staff twelve feet long."

MICHAEL HAYDON (City policeman, 21). I know Cartwright's coffee-shop in Whitecross-street—I know that meetings of Chartists have been held there—I was present at this Court last session, and heard the evidence that was given with respect to a tumult at that place on 29th May—I was not present at it.

THOMAS COPE . I am the publisher of the Times newspaper—I have here the file-copy of the second edition of the Times of 27th July, 184S—it contains a report of a telegraphic dispatch of the reported rising in Ireland—(reads—"Ireland, Thursday morning. In the absence of any report from our corre
spondent, we publish, without vouching for its accuracy, the following intelli
gence, just received from the Electric Telegraph Company:—Liverpool, Thursday morning. The following intelligence was received by special engine last evening by the editor of the Dublin Post:—'The whole of the south of Ireland is in rebellion, the station at Thurles is on fire, the rails for several miles torn up, and the mob's intention is to detain the engines as they arrive at Clonmel. The fighting is dreadful. The people arrived in masses. The Dublin Club leaders were there. The troops were completely overpowered; many refused to act. The military at Carrick have shown disaffection, and have been driven back, and their quarters fired. At Kilkenny the contest is pro
ceeding,
and here too the mob are said to have been successful. No news from Waterford or Cork.' "

Prisoner's Defence. Having been arraigned at the bar of this Court to-day to answer to a charge preferred against me by the Gentlemen of the Govern
ment, it is not my intention to follow them through all the mazes and intricacies of the law, for I believe the present existing laws to be so compli
cated and confused, as to pass my humble powers of conception; but although I stand at the bar of this Court to-day, I trust that no man in this Court will for a moment suppose that I stand here accused of any crime, or any act of dishonesty that I may have committed against my fellow-men; no, not with
standing all the difficulties that I feel surround me this day, it is a consolation to me to know, that in standing here my honour and integrity as a man, are not impeached; I am here merely for differing from the Government in opinion; for that, and that alone, and in support of that assertion, allow me to draw your attention to the materials out of which this prosecution has been framed. You have heard that on the evening of the 28th July, a meeting was held at the Chartist-hall, Webber-street, and that I at that meeting delivered a speech which has been termed seditious. Was there ever a more diabolical, a more fabricated statement urged on the face of an indictment than that upon which I have this day been accused? I have been accused of having mali
ciously and wilfully excited her Majesty's subjects to rebellion, and so forth. Now I contend that the remarks I made use of at that meeting are support
able by historical facts. You have heard from the evidence of Wm. Counsel, the Government reporter, that I felt a pleasure and satisfaction in expressing my opinion of the policy of the British Government towards Ireland, and in moving the resolution condemnatory of the base and unconstitutional acts of the British Legislature I stated that it was necessary to refer to history to support the assertion which I then made, and on referring to history, what do we find? why, that up to the period of 1782, Ireland was free from English legislative thraldom, and it was not till that date that the Act 6 Geo. III. passed, which claimed and exercised the power of British legislation over Ireland. Now the mere passing of that Act, even of itself, admits the pre
existence of freedom, and leads us to inquire how a nation, that long before 1300 possessed its own legislature, came to give up to a foreign power the right of self-government. What do we find? Why, that the Irish parliament, backed by the Irish people, exerted this power of independence in legisla
tion for their own country. But passing over that period, and coming down to the time of the American war, when that people revolted against England for attempting to trample on their legislative rights, and insisted upon perfect legislative independence with such an ardour and force of arms, that England became alarmed and proposed a final adjustment, which was entered into. But England never yet preserved or performed a treaty with Ireland; and thus we perceive one encroachment after another, until we come down to the period of 1800, when the Act of Union was carried by the most diabolical and contemptible means that was ever resorted to for a class legislation; which atrocious acts of plunder has at last plunged the country into all the horrors of insurrection. Such has been the policy of the English Government towards Ireland. Will you tell the world, by your verdict this day, that it is sedition for a man to sympathise with Ireland's wrongs? To tell them that they have a right to use any constitutional means which they have in their power to remove the tyrants from power who have brought them to death's door by heir acts of tyranny?
