Will you tell the world, by your verdict, that it is sedition to tell your countrymen to organize and oppose the same tyrants

who are trying to reduce you to the same depths of misery and degradation? Will you tell the world that it is sedition for a man to try to unite English
men and Irishmen together? Gentlemen, I hope better things of you; are: are men, I presume, who are moving in what are called the middle circles of society, some of whom, I doubt not, have sons who, when brought to years of maturity, will have to grapple and struggle with the affairs of business; think seriously of the ruin and misery which the atrocious policy of the Government is entailing upon you by seeking to destroy thac spirit of justice and growing intelligence which the working classes are determined to enjoy, and to remove the fruits of those who have so long laboured for the working classes, just as they are beginning to make their appearance. But the working classes are beginning to understand that they are the wealth-pro
ducers, and are entitled to receive a proportionate share of enjoyment, and they are determined to meet from time to time to consider what steps are likely to promote their cause, and to discuss and promote tbeir principles and if the noble Lord at the head of the Government supposes that by employing a few thousand policemen to break the heads of honest and hard-working men, and by employing spies to procure convictions, through the means of prejudiced juries, he will ultimately find himself mistaken. The avidity with which the great majority of the people of this country have adopted the principles of the people's charter, seems greatly to have frightened the noble Lord at the head of the Government; and no wonder, when the eyes of the people being to open, and they begin to inquire how the taxes have become so enormously increased, and when they see nothing but bankruptcy and ruin staring then in the face. This has led a great many men to desire a speedy change in public affairs, and to inquire how this state of things has been brought about, The noble lord has said that the disaffection of the Chartists has been to such an unparalleled extent, as has obliged him to increase the rates in order to support the men who had come forward in order to put down that disaffec
tion; but this lame story has only led the people to make further inquiries, and to adopt such measures as to bring about a better state of things, and the means they had decided upon are the principles of the people's charter. Do you know those principles, Gentlemen?—if not, allow me to refer you to that excellent little pamphlet written by Dr. M'Douall, wherein be states what they are, and what they want. I believe that the principles of the people's charter contain one of the best political creeds that was ever submitted. Its points are easy of conception, and its principles are just. It does not, as some assert, wish to destroy one class of society to raise up another, nothing of the sort; but it does wish to give to all a just political equality. It seeks to give to every man of sound mind, untainted by crime, a voice in the election of the representatives of the people. It seeks to destroy a pro
perty qualification, for the purpose of giving men of talent, without pecuniary resources, an opportunity of obtaining a seat in Parliament. It seeks to pre
vent that disgraceful intimidation and bribery which is carried on under the present system. It seeks to shorten the duration of Parliaments, to keep the representatives of the people honest. It seeks, as nearly as possible, equal electoral districts, so as to give as fair a representation of the country at large as can possibly be obtained. These are some of the leading principles of the charter; and for calling upon my fellow-countrymen to organise, never to cease their agitation, but to avail themselves of every opportunity to forward their cause, I have been charged with all the foul and malignant falsehoods contained in the indictment; and for this the learned counsel wishes to obtain conviction. I feel assured, Gentlemen, that I need not remind you of the

good conduct and forbearance of the people on 10th April, when the Govern
ment mustered all their forces, and banded all their troops, to prevent the people from getting free access to Parliament. I feel assured that you are already convinced that the contents of the indictment are nothing more than a tissue of falsehoods, and that this is only intended for the purpose of putting down public opinion—of destroying the right of public meeting, and making victims of honest men. Do not lend yourselves as the tool of such a Government; but let your manly and consistent verdict this day tell the tyrants of misrule and oppression, that Englishmen shall inherit the ancient rights of their forefathers, and the gratitude of a grateful people will reverence your memories in ages yet to come.

GUILTY . Aged 32.—
Confined Two Years,
fined 10l.,
and to enter into his can recognizances in 100l., and to find two sureties of 50l. each, to keep the peace for five years.

2045.
JAMES MAXWELL BRYSON was indicted
for a like offence.
The ATTORNEY-GENERAL, MESSRS. WELSBY, BODKIN, and CLERK conducted the Prosecution.

FREDERICK BOND HUGHES . I am a short-hand writer. On Friday even
ing, 28th July, I was present at a meeting at the Chartist-hall, Webber-street, Blackfriars-road—I got there a few minutes before eight—about 150 persons were then assembled—the number afterwards increased to the extent of between four and five hundred—they consisted of mechanics—the defend
ant presided as chairman—he was not in the chair before I got into the room, but a few minutes afterwards, as the numbers gradually increased, the chair
man and other parties appeared on the platform—he took the chair without being moved in—he addressed the meeting in the first instance—I took a note of his speech, and have it here—(reads)—"Ladies and Gentlemen, we have met this evening to give utterance to sentiments of sympathy in behalf of a people who have suffered the first shock of the tyrant's vengeance. Whether the intelligence that was received, and generally circulated yesterday, is correct or incorrect it still requires some time to elucidate; but it is very evident that the excuse, and the lame story told by Sir George Grey last night in the House of Commons, tallies very ill with what appears this morning in the papers. A newspaper when it receives intelligence from its correspondent at a distance, know whether to place confidence in the man or not; and it is not likely that so many correspondents would put their heads together to send one and the same story to this country by express, and then the next day contradict every word of it. They must. have stated, the correspondents themselves must have acknowledged, this morning, that they were gross liars, and it is not very likely that they are going to do that for their employers; or else they must have stated that they fell asleep from over fatigue, and dreamt all about it. However it is very evident something is going on in Ireland; what it is we do not exactly know, but it is quite evident this Government is afraid of what is going on in Ireland—(cries of "let us go on here, now is the time)—Gentlemen, if I am your chairman this evening, I hope you will keep order, and if any gentleman makes use of expressions in the body of the Hall, I hope none of you will pay any attention to him, for depend upon it that Gentleman has not any good intention towards your cause, for it is the way in which all Govern
ment spies attempt to get up a disturbance in public meetings; now be upon your guard, I beg of you, for it is quite evident they are sent on purpose to do such things—(a voice, "they ought to be kicked out")—if you are not satisfied with this meeting, and if you have got anything to say, I shall be

happy if you will come on the platform and say it, and all the company besides. I beg of you to have a little patience; do not mind the interrupt
tion, pay no attention to it, that is the best way to get over it—there can be little doubt, as I was stating to you, there must be something doing in Ireland of an extraordinary nature, because even in this day's paper, in the organ of Government, the Times, it mentions the fact that 400 war
rants have been issued against the confederate leaders, by the Lord Lieutenant, in one day; that does not look amicable, or as if things were going on peaceably and quietly. It is stated how many forges were ringing with the manufacture of pikes, in defiance of the police and the authorities. Troops have been leaving every morning from London and other parts to go to that unhappy country, as I must call it. But nevertheless, it is evident that whatever has been done, they have stood the shock very nobly, if shock it has been. There can be very little doubt the sword is drawn and the bullet is flying on the other side of the channel—(Loud cheers)—our rulers may attempt to disguise the fact, but the truth will ultimately come out. There can be no question about it at the present moment, that we are in a very precarious situation: it is for us, however, to remain quiet, and not commit ourselves in any way; and I trust any gentleman who comes up here to say a word this evening, will be very careful of his language, because a very good authority; and we, the Chartists, have great confidence in his authority on law; informed me to-day that this was, according to the new Act, a seditious meeting. However, Gentlemen, I have not withdrawn from what I promised the learned counsel, and that was to take the chair this evening, although he informed me it was seditious; but I trust none of you will allow me to answer for your crimes, it is quite enough if I answer for my own, and all the words upon this Bill I hold in my hand, and all the expressions I have given utterance to I have no objection to go into a Court of Justice and defend, without the aid of Counsel. I do not want any attorney to pick out a flaw in the indictment, or any forensic oratory to get me off; I stand by the principles mentioned in the Bill; I stand by the words I have used, but I hope and trust you will be careful in what you say, for I am answerable for everything you say this evening, the same as if I spoke it myself. With these remarks, Gentlemen, as there are several resolutions to come before this meeting, I trust none of you will overstrain your language; no doubt many of you are warm and enthusiastic in it, and perhaps might feel the spirit rising as it did in Douglas, and you might perhaps say you 'longed to follow to the field some warlike chief, but you must not say that here. With respect to that unfortunate country, Ireland, there can be no doubt also that our Government has sent some of the very harshest—to give it the mildest term—the harshest of their Generals. The last new importation, the oriental slaughterman has been sent over; that gentleman has been sent over, no doubt, for the purpose of slaughtering our Irish brethren, doing it in a Sikh fashion; but it is to be hoped that he will find even a tougher foe than the Sikh was. That General, not to call him by a more harsh name, that human butcher, was in the habit of tying his red bandanna to his bloody sword, and waving it in the air as a signal telegraph to his troops to go in and cut down women, men, and children who came in reach of the weapon. Is he gone to Ireland to do the same thing? He is gone, but whether for that purpose or for a more amicable one we have not the opportunity of knowing. With these few remarks, Gentlemen, I will sit down, and call upon your old friend—and I also beg to state, before I sit down, that it may create no confusion hereafter, that as we are only working people who have got up this meeting—you know a meeting of this

description cannot be got up without expense—and therefore there will be a collection this evening for the purpose of defraying the expense. I hope we shall hare many such numerous meetings as we have now, and as peaceable as the last time we met in this Hall. With these remarks I will sit down, and call upon your old friend and warden, Mr. Keene, to propose the first resolution; and he will also read you a letter from an individual you will be happy to hear would have attended this evening, were it possible; and also, I may state that even the Government hirelings of this country are beginning to use the victims at present in their possession rather harshly; although the Defence-fund has paid for the maintenance of Mr. Vernon in prison, to exempt him from labour, nevertheless he has been forced to pick oakum until his fingers were blistered. This is no flying report; I have had it to-day from the lips of Mrs. Vernon herself; and also I have seen a letter from Dr. M'Douall, which you will soon have the miserable pleasure of reading to
morrow in the 'Star.' That gentleman was thrust into a cell through which the hot water pipes passed, for the purpose of conveying hot water to other apartments of the prison, and there they kept him stewing, I cannot give it any other name; for hoars, until he refused to complain, because it only gratified them; and this gentleman was obliged to take off his coat, waist
coat, and trowsers, and stand up in a corner of the cell to keep life, soul, and body together—(Loud cries of shame). That is the state of your Govern
ment, and the resolution therefore calls upon you loudly to sympathize, par
ticularly with your Irish brethren, who no doubt are suffering similar acts of outrage and violence."

Q. How was that speech received? A. With cheers—a person named Keene then spoke—in the course of his speech he said: "Mitchell saw the misery his country was suffering under; Mitchell knew he must be a sacrifice, but he was willing to be a sacrifice, if by—that sacrifice he could rouse his countrymen to a perfect knowledge of what their rights were"—(three cheers for Mitchell were then given)—the resolution that was proposed by Mr. Keene was, "Resolved, that this meeting views with feeling of distrust and alarm the measure adopted by Her Majesty's Government, and sanctioned by the Im
perial Parliament, for the repression of public opinion in Ireland, as tending to the final severance of all amicable relations between the two countries; and this meeting is further of opinion that the Irish people are fully entitled to a free and independent parliament, and therefore resolves to render to their patriotic brethren in Ireland their cordial sympathy." After Keene, a person named Pedley spoke—the following is a passage in his speech: "I believe, Mr. Chairman, the fact is this, that Ireland is in arms; that they are fighting there; I trust they will speedily gain a victory, and God speed them in their cause!"—that was received with cheers—the resolution was then put by the defendant to the meeting, and carried unanimously—Shell then spoke—I took his speech—Mr. Counsell also took it—we each took the meeting throughout—Shell proposed the second resolution—it was this: "Resolved, that this meeting do solemnly protest against the base and unconstitutional act of the British Legislature, as committed by them in the suspendin? of the Habeas Corpus Act in Ireland; and, further, do hereby tender to Feargus O'Connor, Esq., M. P., and to those gentlemen who supported him, our best thanks for their manly and patriotic conduct on that occasion; and, further, that we do hereby solemnly pledge ourselves that we will render in the hour of trial our full aid and co-operation to our Irish brethren"—I did not take that part where the defendant introduced Mr. Rooney to second a resolution—I have Rooney's speech—he said, "Mr. Chairman, Englishmen, and Irish
men too, I don't know that I am in my place to-night in seconding this reso
lution;

I only come among you as a visitor, but I wish to ask you one or two questions, and I take the opportunity of seconding the resolution to ask to ask you—I wish to know, has organization done its duty among you?—are you satis
fied, Englishmen, that the troops of Britain are sent to slaughter your fellow
men in Ireland I Are you satisfied? We are not satisfied, and we are come to the determination, and let the reporter hear me, that sooner than any shall leave London for Ireland, they must leave it across our corpses (cheers); I made a vow a month ago that I would never say anything at a meeting again; but you must pardon me to-night, for the future nothing but action is required for men; I beg to second the resolution"—there were some words at the con
clusion which escaped me—Mr. Counsell's note is fuller than mine—after that the defendant spoke again—he said, "I rise for the purpose of answering the two questions Mr. Rooney has required to have answered. One was, whe
ther we were organized or not? You are aware we are organized, and that all the acknowledged Chartists belonging to this Hall are organized, and under the proper officers; but every individual who comes into this Hall is not under organization, therefore we have no control over them. The other ques
tion was, whether you were satisfied with the present abuse towards Ireland.? '(cries of 'No!') and whether you would co-operate, and whether you are willing, that is, the organized part of you, because the others are of no use to any party, whether those who belong to the organization are willing to co
operate with the confederates (cries of 'Yes! ') It bas been said some time ago, that the confederates would not come over to us, and that we must go over to them; but this evening is a contradiction to that statement, for the confederates have come to you, and they are willing to co-operate; and I trust Mr. Rooney, when he returns to his club, will inform them that the organized Chartists of the South Lambeth locality, are willing to go hand in hand with any scheme that the confederates have for the amelioration of Ireland"—immediately after that Rooney said, "I beg to tender the best gratitude of the John Mitchell Club, for your sympathy with their unfortunate countryman, and I hope"—there was an interruption there—something was said about a nod being as good as a wink to a blind horse, but I did not write it down—Mr. Counsell has it.

Prisoner. Q. You have mentioned that I took the chair without any cere
mony? A. I did not hear you proposed into the chair—you seemed to me to take it as a matter of course, as if there had been some previous arrangement—no one interrupted me in taking my report—I asked for accommodation as soon as I entered the room, and stated the purpose for which I came—I took, the whole of the meeting verbatim, not merely the heads—there was so much confusion, that if any proposition was made for you to take the chair, I did not take it.

WILLIAM COUNSELL . I attended this meeting in Webber-street on 28th July—I took the speech made by Shell, in proposing the second resolurion—(reading it, as in page 667)—the resolution moved by that speech was put by the chairman to the meeting, and carried—I took a note of what Rooney said after his two questions had been answered by the chairman—he said, "Gen
tlemen, I beg to tender you the best gratitude of the John Mitchell Clab. for your sympathy with my unfortunate countrymen; and I hope" (a voice, "That will do; a wink is as good as a nod to a blind horse.")

JOHN BYWATER (policeman, L 116). I apprehended the prisoner on 2nd Aug., upon a warrant, in Webber-street, where the Chartist meeting was—I searched him at the station, and found on him this paper (produced)"—I knew that he resided at 25, James-street, Lower-marsh, Lambeth—I went here, and there found this sword, this file or pike this book, some papas.

and some cards (producing them: these being read, one was a copy of a resolution—" "Resolved, that this meeting pledge themselves to give coun
tenance and support to the brave patriots of Ireland, who have so nobly opposed the enemies of freedom in their career of unjustifiable bloodshed." One card was as follows—"South London Life and Property Protection Society. Name, James Bryson; entered, May 12, 1848; signed, James Bryson, Secretary pro. tem." Another card referred to the entry of the defendant as a member of the National Charter Association; and the papers related to the formation and rules of The Life and Property Protection Society," which was to consist of an unlimited number of members, above the age of eighteen, each to be armed with a musket or pike, to be paid for by instalments; and the following resolu
tion—"That the householders, and inhabitants of the southern parts of the metropolis, agree to enrol themselves as a Life and Property Protection Society, for the fallowing reasons:—to calm the alarm, and afford a speedy and effective protection to the lives and property of the inhabitants; to save the expense and trouble of summoning and swearing in special constables; to show that the people are not desirous of assaulting the persons, or injuring the property of the middle classes; to maintain peace, law, and order at public meetings; to legally arm themselves, at their own expense, and he ready to act with the authorities whenever the lives and property of the public are in danger:" on the back was written, "Carried.")

Prisoner. Q. You mentioned at Bow-street that you found these articles in a room over the washhouse? A. Yes—I was never in the washhouse, I supposed it to be one—I am not a mechanic—I believe I called this instru
ment a dagger, when I was first examined—I do not know whether I called it a pike—I have seen a burnisher—this is not like any burnisher I have ever seen—I should not imagine it to be one.

(Mr. Thomas Cope read the paragraph from " The Times," as in page 670; the extracts from the record of the conviction of John Mitchell were also read.) Prisoner's Defence. It is not my intention to follow the learned gentleman through all the mazes of the law—first, because I conceive that the late stringent enactments that have been passed for the purpose of crushing those who have embraced the same political opinions which I this day stand here to advocate, are no doubt sufficiently explicit in themselves, to give him all the advantage which a prosecutor requires to enable him to procure a conviction; and secondly, it would be utterly out of my power to do so—being immured in a gaol, I was of course obliged to submit to the discipline of the place; and although I was supplied with materials for writing, and such purposes, yet I was denied the use of those books "which I considered were essential for my defence; this may seem rather strange, nevertheles it is to fact, and this restriction was carried to such an extent, that not only were political pamphlets refused me, but even a sight of the Penny Cyclopœdia, containing a definition of the word "Sedition," had the chaplain's veto affixed to it; and further, I could obtain no knowledge of the specific nature of the charge against me until Saturday, when I heard it very imperfectly in this Court, when I was called up to plead; but whether this is an arrangement for the distinction of political and criminal offenders, or whether it is an established rule of all the prisons in the kingdom, I am not sufficiently con
versant with criminal jurisprudence and prison discipline to determine; but I trust you will at once perceive, that labouring under such disadvantages, it places me in a position not at all calculated to meet the charge, particularly when that charge has been preferred by a gentleman who stands at the top of his profession. But with all these disadvantages, I do not despair of being

able to show you that the part I took in the political sympathy with my brother democrats was nothing more than a justifiable right, inherited by all freemen; nor are you to suppose, because I stand before you unassisted by counsel, that I do so for the purpose of creating sympathy in my behalf I do it from a conviction that any one of you, similarly situated, and having the least regard for your word and honour, would have acted the same; neither are you to suppose that my political associates have abandoned me to my fate; on the contrary, I was no sooner arrested than professional aid was tended and refused, on the ground that however learned the advocate might be or how
ever conversant with the intricacies of his profession, conviction would follow conviction, until once that class of society out of which juries are composed become convinced that to coerce the working classes is but the steppin-stone to their own political and social degradation. I have no doubt that most of you have presided at a public meeting during some period of your life, and, therefore, you are aware that some warmth of language is required on the part of the chairman, that the audience may be made acquainted with the nature of the motives for calling them together; and if I, on the 28th ult., while acting as chairman, gave utterance to language con
trary to law, it was nevertheless dictated by views of humanity. We had received the day before, by public intelligence, a brief account of Irish dis
turbances; and as that people were struggling for political freedom, with
held from them by the same power that kept us in political thraldom, it was but natural we should tender our sympathies at such a crisis, and particularly when our grievances were so closely allied; and I do not think there was anything dangerous in the reply I made to Mr. Rooney, that we were willing to co-operate for the amelioration of the Irish people; common courtery required me to say as much, seeing that that gentleman headed a deputation of fifty members from the Mitchell Club; and certainly, had I returned a less favourable answer, there can be little doubt that a disturbance would have been the consequence, because there were a great number of policemen in disguise, in the room at the time, and they had made several attempts to disturb the meeting during the evening, and a greater number outside fully armed and ready to act at a moment's notice, fully determined to break up the meeting if possible prematurely. I was aware of their intention both inside and outside the room, for I had just received a note from one of those sent to watch their proceedings, telling me to endea
vour to keep order if possibly could, because, said he, 'the butchers outside," this is the policemen, I do not disguise the fact, "are evidently bent on: slaughter, and all they want is a pretext to begin." That the police are capable of doing such things you are all very well aware, from the late in
vestigation into the Bishop Bonner's-field police onslaught. It appears, however, that I conducted the meeting to its close without the least approxi
mation to disorder. Then as for putting the public into great alarm, as the learned gentleman has stated, with respect to the Life and Property Protection Society, I can only tell him that such things are very common, and I should suppose he had seen similar societies in this country and other parts of Europe: it is certainly called a Life and Property Protection Society, and that was by the advice of counsel, and also by the advice of the Mayor of Nottingham, and the society founded in the city of Nottingham was approved of by the Mayor of that city; and our rules are the same. It has nothing to do with the Chartist Association, and in fact that society does not exist at the present. time in any locality that I am aware of, because it was assumed that the Chartist Association was sufficient to answer all the purposes. As for the

organization that is merely an arrangement, as to the internalmanagement of the society, and the documents referring to it, can be purchased at any of the political booksellers for a halfpenny. With respect to Mr. Vernon and D M'Douall, if I had been allowed to have the documents in I could have shown you the very words I read in my speech—or I might have sent for Mrs. Vernon, who no doubt could prove that her husband has sent word to that effect; for she stated in the presence of several other people besides myself, that he had been compelled to pick oakum, and that Feargus O'Connor had been sent to about it. As for Mr. Keene's speech, I can see notthing that very material against me; the fact is, he had had intelligence which is confirmed by another gentleman, Mr. Cope, who belongs to the Times, that Ireland was in a state of disturbance; and surely it was no great harm to repeat at a public meeting, that which appeared in the newspapers. As for the witness Bywater, perhaps there is nothing very objectionable in his evidence, he found the trunk containing these papers unlocked; many of them are not my writing, nor has there been any proof that they are the minutes of any particulars produced at any meeting. With respect to the sympathy we held with the people of Ireland, it is quite clear they were in a state of disturbance at the time I presided at this meeting: and are we on this side of the channel to be deprived of the rights of humanity, and be come amenable to the laws for sympathizing with those on the other side? for who among you, if he has not drained his veins of the milk of human kindness, would not sympathize with an oppressed people, standing on the threshold of civil war, and unable to say how soon the same horrors might surround your own dwellings? Does it not make your blood run cold, when you think that the maladministration of our internal affairs has driven the people to such a course, leaving them no other choice than open insurrection or unregretted starvation? But do not imagine that the coercive measures lately enacted were framed for the purpose of suppressing the spirit of free
dom that is rising in the bosom of the honest mechanic will be laid aside when a few convictions have been obtained; on the contrary, when you have occasion to complain of ministerial oppression, and I do not think that many of you will say that the present Cabinet are doing that which is best calculated to promote contentment and prosperity in the country, that moment will you become subject to the same persecution, and those Acts of Parliament that have been framed to suppress us, will be unscrupulously used for your oppression; you may read a lesson of your future fate in the subterfuge which the present ministry resorted to on 10th April last, when the working classes of the metropolis attempted to exercise what has never been disputed to be a constitutional right,—the right of meeting and going in procession with the petition of their grievances to the Legislature. But, though they were determined to make no concessions, they were aware that there were sample reasons for complaining, and they felt no hesitation in raking up an obsolete act,—an act that had been consigned to oblivion for more than a century and a half, and one that had only been passed to prevent a debauched monarch from being interrupted in his royal revelries by the con gratulations of his loyal subjects;—I allude to the act of Charles II., which suppressed a constitutional right possessed by the people at that period: what are you to expect from such men as these, when you will no longer allow them to rob you with impunity? do you imagine that if Lord John Russell succeeds in suppressing the present discontent among the working classes, which is very doubtful, that he will next Session withdraw his bill for an additional income-tax, merely because it is not consonant with your

wishes, or will he consult the necessity of ministerial extravagance and bring you to compliance by statutory and military coercion—every thinking man in this country follows some political creed, the principles of which either accord with his pecuniary interest or coincide with his con
scientious belief; and I have no hesitation in saying that I believe the Charter to be the best political creed that has been brought forward for the consideration of all classes. Its points are easy of comprehension, and its principles are honest. It does not offer concessions for one class of men, and refuse them to another; nor docs it involve the ruin of one set of men, as the necessary basis upon which another set are to flourish. Can there be any sedition in demanding for every man of sane mind, untainted with crime, and at the age of maturity, a voice in the election of the national representatives? Can it be sedition to demand security for that voice? Is it seditious to require the people's representatives to give an account of their delegation at shorter periods than they have hitherto done? or will it appear seditious to demand that a man of talent, without property, should have an equal right to a scat in the people's parliament which the man with property, but without talent, now possesses? Is it seditious to require that that man shall be remunerated for his labour? Or can you call it sedition to demand that each division of the kingdom be as nearly as possible equally repre
sented? Yet such, Gentlemen, is the sum total of all the points of the Charter—the meaning; of the principles of this new philosophy, which has frightened the Sovereign, alarmed the Ministry, maddened the aristocracy, and distracted the middle classes, but now reigns paramount in the minds of the people. Depend upon it, Gentlemen, when the people understand and adopt a line of policy, neither scaffolds, nor dungeons, nor shackles, will arrest their onward career; nor will unprincipled oppression annihilate their power. You may do as Castlereagh did, thirty years ago, with the Radicals in the west of Scotland, when he emptied the gaols and bridewells of their criminal inmates, and set the felon free, that he might make room for honest Reformers: and although he brought some to the block, and sent some few into exile, yet radicalism prospered, and at this day stands high in the estimation of political reformers.

2046.
WILLIAM SMITH and
ELIZABETH BROWN
, burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Joseph Eden, and stealing 2 shirts, 1 pair of stockings, and 1 handkerchief, value 5s. 6d.; his goods.—2nd COUNT, for receiving the same.

ELIZABETH EDEN . I am the wife of Joseph Eden, of Richmond. On the evening of 17th July I was the last person up—I saw all the fastening secure about twelve o'clock—next morning I came down about seven—I was the first person up, and found the house in very great confusion—the kitchen window was open, and a pane of glass broken, sufficiently large for a person to put their hand through and undo the window—I missed a pair of my son's boots, two shirts, a pair of stockings, a blue and white cotton handker
chief, and a tin box, containing about 18d. or 2s. in money—they are my husband's and son's property—I had seen them safe the previous night—the shirts had been washed, and were wet—I know the stockings by my own darning, and the shirts are marked by me, "J. E.," my husband's initials—I know the handkerchief by the pattern, and its being a little torn.

JOHN PAYNE (policeman, T 252). About four o'clock, on the afternoon of 18th July, I was on duty at Old Brentford, which is about three miles from Richmond and saw Brown—I had received information, and asked her what she had got in her bundle—she said, "Two shirts"—I asked whether they were her own—she said, no, they were her brother's—I asked where her brother was—she said, at the public-house (pointing to the One Tun); that she was going to sell the shirts for her brother—I went to the One Tun, and found no one there—I asked what the shirts were marked with—she said, "Red"—I asked what the initials were—she said she could not tell me—I afterwards showed them to Mrs. Eden—she identified them—these are them (produced).

EMANUEL HARRIS (policeman, V 184). In consequence of information, I went to a pawnbroker's, at Brentford, and found some boots—I heard Brown say at the station-house that the shirts and boots were her brother's, and that she had pawned them—she said her brother was outside—I went outside, found Smith there, and brought him in—I asked Brown if that was the person she wanted—she said, "Yes"—I asked him where he got the boots—he said they were his own, he had them made at Northampton—I asked him if he sent her to pledge them—he said he did, he gave 14s. for them—I asked him what stockings he had on—he pulled up his trowsers, and I found these (produced), which Mrs. Eden identifies—I asked him where he got them—he made no answer—I had seen him about 100 yards from the house about twelve o'clock on the night of the 17th—I do not know whether he was alone or not—he is a stranger to me.

WILLIAM LINEY (policeman, T 5). The male prisoner told me the two shirts were his, and that he had them made in Hampshire—I said, "Are they marked?"—he said, "Yes"—I asked how—he said he did not know—I got the shirts from Brown.
ABRAHAM REED . I am assistant to Mr. Reed, a pawnbroker, at Brentford. I produce a pair of boots and a shirt, pledged on 18th July, by Brown—the ticket has "Ann Brown" on it (produced).
JOHN EDEN . These are my boots—I know them by the wear—they were safe that night.

ELIZABETH EDEN
re-examined. These shirts and stockings are my hus
band's property—here is the mark.
Smith's Defence. I found the bundle in a hedge.
Brown's Defence. I met this prisoner; he said he had had no breakfast; I said I had had none, and I pledged the things to get some money; he is not my brother.

SMITH—
GUILTY of Stealing. Aged 17.

BROWN—
GUILTY of Receiving. Aged 72.

2047.
JOHN SAUNDERS and
GEORGE JONES
, unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.

MARY SYEDS . My husband is a tobacconist, in Rotherhithe Wall. On 15th Aug., Saunders came for half an ounce of tobacco—he paid me with a very new shilling of the Queen's reign—I gave him change for it, and put it into my pocket—I had two old shillings there—a policeman came—I took the three shillings out of my pocket, and at once recognized this one pro
duced, which I had taken of Saunders—the other two were King William's—I gave it to the policeman—this is like the paper of tobacco I sold to Saunders.
ROBERT WILLIAM ANDERSON . I am a fancy soap-maker, of Deptford.

On 15th Aug., Saunders came and asked for half an ounce of bear's greases—he gave me a Victoria shilling—I gave him 10 1/2 d. change, and he left an officer, came in directly, and I gave him the shilling—I had but one other which was Georce the Third's—the officer followed the prisoner—I followed the officer—I fell in with the two prisoners down a turning—they were greasing their hair and laughing—I told Saunders he came to my house just now to buy some bear's grease—he said, "Yes"—I told him he gave me a bad shilling—he said, "Did I"—I said, "You know you did"—he was going to put his hand into his left hand pocket to give me some money, and Jones said, "No, not that pocket"—he put his hand then into his right pocket, and gave me a good shilling—I then asked him for the 10 1/2 d., and he gave it me from the same pocket lie took the good shilling from—I collared him, and called the officer.

JOHN WHITLAMB (policeman, M 89). On 15th Aug. I went to Mrs. Symm's after Saunders came out—she gave me this shilling—I had seen the prisoners before together, and afterwards I followed them—Saunders went into Mr. Anderson's—Jones was about 100 yards off, apparently watching the door—Saunders came out, and I followed the two prisoners to Hughes' Fields—I saw them rubbing their hands on their heads—I took Saunders.

THOMAS WEST (policeman, M 249). I went into Mr. Anderson's shop—he gave me this shilling—I followed the prisoners—I afterwards saw Mr. Anderson with them—he called me—I took Jones, and found this tobacco in his pocket.
CALEB EDWARD POWELL . I am inspector of coin to the Mint—these shillings are both counterfeit, and cast in the same mould.

SAUNDERS—
GUILTY . Aged 22.

JONES—
GUILTY . Aged 23.

2048.
ANN PHILLIPS
, for a like offence.

ARTHUR BLUNT . I live in Regent-street, Lambeth. On 4th Aug. the prisoner came to my shop, and purchased a tea-pot for 6d.—she gave me half-a-crown—she was on my right—I gave her the change, and she moved to my left side—she said, "This is not right, I purchased the tea-pot for 3d.—I said it was right, she had purchased it for 6d. she said she would not have it, she would give me my money again—she gave me two shillings, one was bad—I said I did not give her that bad shilling—she said I did—the shillings I gave her were what I had taken of a customer not five minutes before—they were white—the one she returned was black—several people assembled—a man came from the other side of the way, I had seen him and another man with the prisoner before—he came close to her, and looked over her shoulder, and asked what was the matter—I looked at him, and he went away directly—I believe the white shilling has not been found—I said to the prisoner, "This is bad money, I shall keep it and give you in charge"—she walked into my parlour, and begged very much to be dis
charged, and said if I would give her the tea-pot she would go about her business—I called a policeman, and gave her in charge.

MARY SHERIDAN . I searched the prisoner at the station—I asked what it was for—she said, "For passing a bad shilling"—I asked if she had got—she said, "No"—I found 1s. in her bosom, which I marked, and gave to the inspector—she called me very bad names—I said it would be the worse for her, as I should tell the Magistrate—she said, "You have got me now can't be any worse."
JOSEPH WILKINS (policeman, L 81.) I took the prisoner on 4th Aug. Mr. Blunt gave this shilling to the inspector, and he gave it me, and this other also.
ASSOLAM ARNOLD . This shilling I received from Mr. Blunt, and this other from Mrs. Shann.
CALEB EDWARD POWELL . These shillings are both counterfeit.

GUILTY . Aged 26.—
Confined Four Months.

2049.
JAMES MURRAY
, for a like offence.

SAMUEL SEYMOUR LOWDEN . I am a baker of Union-place, Clapham. On 26th July the prisoner came into my shop about half-past four o'clock for an Abernethy biscuit—it came to a penny—he put a shilling on the counter—I took it up, and said, "This is bad, have you got another "—he said, "No "—I bent it, and said, "I will get a policeman"—I stepped round the counter, and went to the door—he ran off as fast as he could—Barker went after him—I gave the shilling to the officer.

HENRY BARKER . I was in Mr. Dawson's shop—I saw the prisoner run out—I went after him—I saw him join another man—one gave something to the other—the prisoner went into Mr. Williams' shop—I waited outside—he came out, and Mr. Williams came out—the prisoner joined the other man—they ran off—Mr. Williams and I ran after them, overtook them, and got an officer.

THOMAS WILLIAMS . I am a grocer of Clapham. On 26th July the pri
soner came to my shop for half an ounce of tobacco—he gave me a shilling—I gave him 10 1/2 d. change—he went out—I found the shilling was bad—I came to the door—the prisoner was gone—Barker spoke to me—we went in pursuit of him—we saw him and the other man running—they ran 200 or 300 yards; they then stopped—I told the prisoner he gave me a bad shilling—he offered to take it back and give me another—he took out two sixpences and showed me—I gave him in charge—the other man got away—I marked the shilling, and gave it to the officer.

WILLIAM OWEN TUPPNY (policeman, V 48.) I produce these two shillings one—I received from Mr. Williams, the other from Mr. Dawson—I found two sixpences, a fourpenny-piece, and some halfpence on the prisoner, all good.
CALEB EDWARD POWELL . These shillings are both counterfeit.

GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Confined Four Months.

2050.
ELIZA GIBBS
, for a like offence.

MARIA SUSANNAH BALL . On 11th July, I was in a pastry-cook's shop in Kennington-lane—the prisoner came in for a bun—I served her—she gave me a shilling, which I laid in a drawer where there was no other silver—she remained about three minutes and went away—Mr. Norman came in, and looked at the shilling—it was bad—he gave it to the officer.

MARIA ELIZABETH EVERETT . My husband keeps a beer-shop. On 11th July, the prisoner came for half-a-pint of porter—she gave me a bad shilling—I bent it, and gave it her back—she gave me a good one, and left—I believe this is it—(produced).

THOMAS WINTER (policeman, L 158.) I received this shilling from Mr. Norman, in Mrs. Ball's presence—I took the prisoner—I found in her hand 8d. in copper—Mr. Norman took this shilling out of her right hand—it was rather bent.
CALEB EDWARD POWELL . These shillings are both counterfeit, and cast in the same mould.
Prisoner's Defence. She said she gave me a 6d., and 5d. in halfpence, and I had but one penny; if I had had the change, it must have been found on me.

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Four Months.

2051.
SARAH FISHER
, for a like offence.

FANNY BISHOP . On 30th June, the prisoner came to came shop in High-street, Borough, for two yards of straw-beading—she paid me a half-crow—I put it into the cash-box, and gave her change—she left—the officer came in, I gave him the same half-crown—there was no other there—on 5th July, the prisoner came again for one yard of the same, and paid me a shilling—I said it was bad—I gave it to Mr. Draper, and the prisoner was taken.
MOSES DRAPER . I gave the shilling which Bishop gave me to the officer—I saw her take it of the prisoner.
JOHN WHITLAMB (policeman, M 106). I took the prisoner—this is the shilling and half-crown.
CALEB EDWARD POWELL . These are both counterfeit.

GUILTY . Aged 27.—
Confined Four Months.

2052.
CHARLES GREY
, for a like offence.
MESSRS. SCRIVEN and CLERK conducted the Prosecution.

ELIZABETH WRIGHT . My husband keeps a beer-shop in Tooley-street On 6th Aug., the prisoner was there in the evening—I served him with half-a-pint of beer—he paid me a penny—he then asked me for two sixpences for a shilling—I had not two sixpences—I gave him sixpence and sixpenny. worth of halfpence—he gave me a shilling, which I put into the till where there was no other silver—in about five minutes he called fora pint of beer—the girl gave it him—he gave her a shilling, which she gave me—I said it was bad, and returned it to him—he sent me twopence for the beer—he then had half a screw of tobacco, and sent a bad shilling, which I returned—I looked at the first shilling which I had put into the till—it was bad—the prisoner took it out of my hand directly and went away with all the three shillings—the officer has one shilling which I believe to be the one I had from the prisoner first and put into the till.
Prisoner. Did not your husband say he gave the policeman a shilling'? A. No.

WILLIAM WRIGHT . I am the husband of Elizabeth Wright. She called me down stairs on 5th Aug.—I saw the prisoner running out—I followed him, secured him before he got across the street, brought him back, and said. "You have run away with change for a shilling"—he laid down half-a-crown—I gave him 1s. 6d., and sent for a policeman—the prisoner went to a public-house and sat behind the door—I gave him in custody—he was brought back to my house and searched, and one bad shilling found on him.

JAMES BARRON . I keep a public-house. On 5th Aug., the prisoner came to my house for a pint of beer—he paid me in coppers, drank his beer, and left—he came back and said he would have a drop of gin—he gave me a shilling—I put it into the till—there was another shilling, a sixpence, and two half-crowns there—it was not put with the other money, but in a corner—the other shilling that was there was battered—the officer came in—I market the shilling the prisoner gave me, and sent it after the officer by Wallis.
Prisoner. Did you not give change for half-a-crown while I was lighting
my pipe? A. No—I did not take out the shilling and pass it to some person to see whether it was good.
MARY WALLINGTON . I gave the shilling which my matser gave me to Hansell, the officer.

DAVID HANSELL (policeman, M 117). I got this bad shilling from the pri
soner, and this other from Wallis—I found on the prisoner 7s. 2 3/4 d. in good money.
Prisoner. Q. Did you not hear the woman say her husband gave you one of the shillings? A. No.
CALEB EDWARD POWELL . These two shillings 3re counterfeit, and cast in the same mould.

(The prisoner put in a written defence, stating that he put down 2s. 6d. to bet at a public-house, and mixed it with money belonging to other men, and after
wards found that he must have taken up bad money instead of his own.)

GUILTY .—
Confined Four Months.

2053.
EDWARD LAWRENCE and
THOMAS BARRETT
, for a like offence.

GEORGE SIMPSON . On 1st July, between four and five o'clock in the morning, I was with my mother in the Borough-market—the prisoners came up and bought eighteen gallons of raspberries, and paid 8s. 3d. for them—Lawrence gave me four half-crowns, which I gave to my mother—she gave me 2s. 3d. change, which I gave to him—Barrett was standing by his side, and had joined in the bargain—I took the raspberries to the opposite side of the market—they were put into one of the prisoner's baskets in a barrow—the pri
soners returned in half an hour, and Barrett bought six gallons of raspberries—Barrett paid roe balf-a-crown and a shilling, which I gave to my mother—the prisoners went away—they came back again with a man and woman—the prisoners persuaded them to buy some raspberries, for which they paid three half-crowns—I gave them to my mother—I saw the prisoners together in the Borough-market again on 8th July, and gave them into custody.

Cross-examined by MR. CHARNOCK. Q. Had you seen them in the mean
time? A. No—I do not know that they have attended the market four or fire years—I found out that these half-crowns were bad about half an hour after the man and woman left, which was about six o'clock—I had not sold many goods that morning—Keys had not paid me any half-crowns—I did not sell fruit to other persons afterwards—Mr. Fricker has a stand near my mother's.

HANNAH SIMPSON . I am the mother of George Simpson. I was in the Borough-market selling fruit, on 1st July—I saw the prisoners come for eighteen gallons of raspberries—I saw Lawrence pay my son four half-crowns—he gave them to me, I put them in my pocket—the prisoners went away they returned, and Barrett bought some raspberries which came to 3s. 6d.—I saw him pay a half-crown and a shilling to my son—he brought it to me—I put it in the same pocket with the others—no one had been to pur
chase fruit in the meantime—the prisoners went away, and came back with a man and woman—they bought some raspberries—I cannot tell what money my son gave me, but I put it into my pocket—no one had been to deal in the meantime—I had no money in my pocket but what I had from my son—after I had sold the last lot, something was said, and I took eight half-crowns and two shillings out of my pocket.
Crass-examined. Q. You do not know which were the three nor which

were the five? A. No, but they were all bad—I marked them and gave them to the beadle about two minutes after the four people were gone—I had no other half-crown in my pocket—the prisoners did not pay six shilling and five sixpences—I had not received any money from Keys—I never saw the prisoners before.
HENRY CHANNING . I am beadle of the Borough-market. I produce the eight half-crowns and two shillings which Mrs. Simpson gave me.
Cross-examined. Q. Do you know these men? A. I have seen them about the market.

CALEB EDWARD POWELL . These eight half-crowns are all counterfeit—these two shillings are counterfeit, and cast in the same mould—three of these half-crowns have been cast in one mould, and five in another.
(The prisoners received good characters.)

LAWRENCE—
GUILTY . Aged 22.

BARRETT—
GUILTY . Aged 24.

2054.
JAMES STEVENS
, stealing a show-case and pictures, value 22l.; the goods of
Antoine Claudet; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 38.—
Transported for Seven Years.

2055.
HENRY MORTIMORE and
JOHN LUC KEN
, stealing 1 hand
kerchief, value 1s.; the goods of
John Ellis, from his person.

JOHN ELLIS . On 6th Aug., about half-past six o'clock in the evening, I was in Battersea-fields—I felt a tug at my pocket, turned, and saw the prisoners close behind me—Mortimore was the closest to me—I missed my handkerchief, which I had seen safe a quarter of an hour before—the prisoners were taken—my handkerchief was found on Lucken—this is it.

WILLIAM OLIVER . I was with Mr. Eliis, and saw the prisoners close behind him—one said to the other, "He has got his hand on it"—in about two minutes I heard of the loss—I went after the prisoners, and found them together—I found the handkerchief on Lucken.
GEORGE MARQUARD (police-sergeant, V 21). I saw the two prisoners in company—I took them, and found this handkerchief and three others, on Lucken.
Mortimore. One of them belongs to me.
(Lucken received a good character.)

MORTIMORE—
GUILTY . Aged 19.

LUCKEN—
GUILTY . Aged 18.

2056.
ELIZABETH HOSTLER
, stealing 11 shillings and 1 sixpence, the money of
William Cyrus Bond, her master; having been before convicted; to which she plended

GUILTY . Aged. 55.—
Confined Eighteen Months ,

2057.
THOMAS GUBBINS
, stealing 1 barrow, value 1l. 10s.; the goods of
Daniel Holden, his master; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 37.—
Confined Three Months.

2058.
WILLIAM CLEGG
, stealing 2 pairs of boots, value 10s.; the goods of
George Sheaves: also, 1 pair of boots, value 10s.; the goods of
William Robert Jack: also, 1 pair of shoes, value 8s.; the goods of
Andrew Moore; having been before convicted; to all of which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Confined Twelve Months.

2059.
GEORGE ROBERTS
, stealing 1 watch, value 30s.; the goods of
Sarah Scutchey; having been before convicted; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Transported for Ten Years.

2060.
JOHN SMITH and
JOHN ROGERS
, stealing 2 coats, value 4l.; the goods of
Henry Tarrant; to which

SMITH pleaded
GUILTY .

ROGERS pleaded
GUILTY .

2061.
MARY BRADY
, stealing 3 sovereigns, the moneys of
George Lor
man, from his person; and
JOHN BEASLEY
, as an accessary after the fact.

GEORGE LAWS . I am a wheelright, of Lambeth-wall. I met the prisoner Brady, and went with her to the Elephant and Castle, and then to a house—I had 5l. 4s.—three sovereigns were in my waistcoat-pocket—Brady wanted me to go in—I would not—she unbuttoned my coat and took them out—I caught her by the shawl—Beasley came up, and said, "If you don't let that woman go I will knock your b----y eyes out"—I am sure Brady's hand was in my pocket—I had my money safe ten minutes before—I had my hand upon it.

SUSANNAH THOMPSON . I heard a noise, and opened my window—Lorman charged Brady with robbing him of three sovereigns—she said she had not—he caught her shawl—Beasley came up, and said, "If you don't let the woman go I will knock your b----y eyes out."
Beasley. I did not say such a word.

EMMA BURGESS . I heard the quarrel—Lorman said she had robbed him of three sovereigns, wrapped up in paper—Beadey came up, and said, "What is the matter?"—she said, "This man accuses me of robbing him of three sove
reigns"—he said, "Why don't you let her go?" or words to that effect, and she went away.
GEORGE BUTT (policeman, P 340). I heard a call, and went to the spot—Lorman had got Beasley by the collar, and Brady's shawl in his hand—I found Brady afterwards.

BRADY—
GUILTY . Aged 21.

BEASLEY—
GUILTY . Aged 32.

2062.
WALTER FITZGERALD
, stealing 1 bag and 1lb. 4ozs. Weight of tobacco, value 1s. 5d.; the goods of
John Parson, in a vessel on the Thames.

JOHN PARSON . I belong to the Rose, lying in the Thames—the prisoner was employed on board—I had a bag and 4ozs. of tobacco in my chest, in the forecastle—I missed it, and found it under the prisoner's waistcoat—I asked if he had been stealing my tobacco—he said no, it was given him by another man—he would not say who—it was safe a quarter of an hour before.
JOSHUA JUDGE (Thames-police inspector). The prisoner was given into my charge—he said somebody gave him the tobacco—he would not say who; I called all the people up before him.
Prisoner. The man has left the vessel.

GUILTY . Aged 29.—
Confined Three Months.

2063.
THOMAS CHERRY
, burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Mary Ann Higgs, and stealing 1 shawl, value 7s., her goods.

MARY ANN HIRES . I live at Martyr-street, St. George's, Southwark—I have known the prisoner some time; he is a costermonger. On Sunday night, 5th Aug., I fastened my house up about nine o'clock—I came home about three in the morning, unlocked the door, and went to bed—in about twenty minutes I heard footsteps come down the staircase;—I got and said, "Good God! who is that in the room?"—the prisoner said, "You b----y whore, I have come to murder you!"—I believe he had got in at the window—he has been in the habit of coming in that way—I missed a shawl from my table.

Cross-examined by MR. CHARNOCK. Q. Other people came into the house? A. Yes—I had lived with the prisoner at his aunt's fora week or ten days—I went there and charged him—he said he knew nothing about the shawl—I have no reason to believe that he took it—he has never taken anything before—three panes of glass were broken.
NOT GUILTY .

2064.
EDWARD CLAYTON
, unlawfully obtaining, by false pretences, 36 yards of muslin, 87 yards of dimity, and other articles, value 7l. 17s.; with intent to defraud
Robert Johnson, and other persons of the same: also, 4 1/2 yards of carpet, and 90 yards of damask, value 6l. 13s. 9d.; with intent to defraud
John Swinford; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Transported for Seven Years.

2065.
ELLEN FOX
, stealing 1 blanket, 1 quilt, 3 brooches, and other articles, value 3l. 4s.; the goods of
Robert Loveless.

SOPHIA LOVELESS . My husband's name, is Robert—we live at Market-street, Kennington. The prisoner took our front parlour, as a lodging for herself and her paralytic mother, who was to come on the Monday—she gave me 1s. deposit, and took possession—in the evening she asked roe for a towel, to get a little meat, and she went out, telling me twice to take care of myself—she did not come back—I went into her room about nine o'clock—I missed the sheets, blankets, quilt, and a work-box—I had seen them safe that evening—the mother never came.
(The prisoner received a good character.)
GUILTY . Aged 30.

2066.
ELLEN FOX was again indicted
for stealing 1 blanket, 1 looking-glass, and other articles, value 1l. 19s.; the goods of
Stephen Leonard Wynn.

MARY ANN WYNN . I am the wife of Stephen Leonard Wynn. On Wednes
day, 12th April, the prisoner took a room of me for herself and her paralyzed mother, who was to come on the Saturday—she did not come, and the pri
soner went out, saying she was going to the Birmingham Railway to meet her, and never came back—I broke her room door open, and missed the blankets, sheets, fire-irons, looking-glass, frying-pan, and a knife and fork—I have not seen them since.

GUILTY . Aged 30.—
Confined Twelve Month
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

2067.
ALFRED FERRELL ,
THOMAS STARKE , and
FRANCIS MPREVELLE
, stealing 3 pairs of trowsers and 4 shirts, value 15s.; the goods of
Frederick George Aubyn; Ferrell having been before convicted.

JAMES CLARK (policeman, P 108). On 7th Aug., about four o'clock in the morning, I was on Westow-hill, Norwood, and saw the prisoners about. fifty yards from Mr. Aubyn's—Ferrell and Starke had a bundle—I knew them—I called to them to stop—they ran away—I went after threw down the bundles, and ran on for about fifty yards—I caught Starke and

Ferrell, and took them back to Mr. Aubyn's, and picked up the two bundles on the way—they contained three pairs of trowsers and four shirts—Ferrell said he picked the clothes up—afterwards he said Umprevelle gave him them to carry—the clothes are marked—Mr. Aubyn's store-house is attached to his house at the back—on the 18th I took Umprevelle at Dulwich, and told him the charge—he said he was perfectly aware of the charge, but had nothing to do with taking the property, that he never touched it; but was compelled, by threats, to go with them.

WILLIAM EDGAR . I am drill-master at Mr. Aubyn's establishment for pauper poor. The prisoners were there some years ago—these trowsers and shirts are under my care—they belong to Frederick George Aubyn, and were kept in a store-room attached to the back of the premises; the prisoners knew that—on 6th Aug., between three and four o'clock in the afternoon, I locked the store up and put the key in my pocket—I saw it secure in the evening, and found it broken open next morning, and missed several articles—I cut these trowsers out, and marked them.

CHARLES HAVAR (policeman). I produce a certificate of Ferrell's con
viction—(read—Convicted June, 1848, and confined one month and whipped)—he is the boy.
(Starke received a good character.)

FERRELL—
GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Twelve Months.

STARKE—
GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Confined Six Months.

UMPREVELLE—
GUILTY . Aged 15.—
Confined Three Months.

2068.
JOHN BETTS
, stealing 5 sacks, value 5s.; the goods of
Henry Noyce; and
WILLIAM BETTS
, receiving the same; John Betts having been before convicted.

HENRY NOYCE . I keep a coal-shed, in "East-street, Lambeth. On 1st Aug., at half-past six o'clock, I saw my sacks in the shop—I went out, came back at ten, and missed five coke-sacks—next evening I received information from Shaw, and went to 93, East-street, Lambeth, and saw Eliza Delay and another female, and next morning, about seven o'clock, four small sacks were brought to me, which I refused to accept—if they were mine they had been cut up, or tarred over afresh—on the 5th William Betts was brought by Webber—I gave him in charge.
ALFRED SHAW . I live at Sun-place, Kennington. On 1st Aug., about ten minutes to eight at night, I saw John Betts come out of Mr. Noyce's shop with some sacks under his arm, and go towards Lambeth.

ELIZA DELAY . I am wife of William Delay, of East-street, Lambeth-walk. The prisoners lodge with us. On 1st Aug. they came home together. One of them had some sacks—they put them in the back yard—next morn
ing about seven, I saw them cutting them up, and making them into smaller ones—they finished about four o'clock, and took them out. Mr. Noyce came the same evening, and I told him what I had seen—the prisoners were not at home—next morning I told William Betta what Mr. Noyce said—he said his brother had run away.

JOSEPH JORDAN (policeman, 88 L). I took William Betts on the 5th, and asked if he had any objection to come with me to Mr. Noyce's—he said No, he knew what it was for—I took him, and he was given in charge—he said he knew nothing about it.

John Betts's Defence. On the week before this happened, I called and asked Mr. Noyce to give me a job; he told me to call next week, and he would give me something to do; I got some corn sacks which I thought

would suit him, and took them there; I stamped with my foot in the shop, and no one came; I took them home, and put them in the yard; we were making sacks there next day; they were not Noyce's but another man's; I took them home to him.
William Betts's Defence. My brother engaged me to help him.

ALFRED SHAW
re-examrned. George had nothing when he went in—his hands were in his pockets—I went into a shop, came out, and he had got the sacks under his arm.

HENRY NORCE
re-examined. I did tell him to look down,;—and said perhaps I might give him a job.
HENRY BARRY . I produce a certificate of John Betts's former convinction (read—Convicted Jan. 1848, confined Ten days)—I was present—he is the person.

JOHN BETTS—
GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Transported for Seven Years.

WILLIAM BETTS—
NOT GUILTY .
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, SEP. 18TH, 1848.
